'''Estonianization''' is the changing of one's personal names from other languages into Estonian, or the development of [[Estonian language]], culture and identity within educational and other state institutions through various programs. ==Family names== Before 1920, some fifty percent of Estonian surnames were of foreign origin.George Kurman, ''The Development Of Written Estonian'', Routledge 1997, {{ISBN|0-7007-0380-2}}, page 85 At the beginning of the 1930s, [[President of Estonia|president]] [[Konstantin Päts]] introduced a nationwide Estonianization program for family names. During this campaign thousands of Estonian citizens living in [[Estonia]] voluntarily changed their original family names. ===Notable estonianized names=== *Karl August Einbund → [[Kaarel Eenpalu]] *Gerhardt Esperk → [[Ants Eskola]] *Harald Rudolf Klein → [[Ruut Tarmo]] *Hans Laipman → [[Ants Laikmaa]] *Kristjan Trossmann → [[Kristjan Palusalu]] ==Integration== The integration policy is aimed at strengthening of Estonian identity among the nation's populace, to develop shared values, identity, and pride in being a citizen of Estonia; with respect and acceptance of cultural differences among Estonian residents. ===Education=== On 14 March 2000 the [[Government of Estonia]] adopted “State Programme “Integration in Estonian society 2000-2007". Main areas and aims of the integration established by the program are linguistic-communicative, legal-political and socio-economical. The Program has four sub programs: education, the education and culture of national minorities, the teaching of Estonian to adults and social competence. The aim of the sub-programs is to be achieved via the learning of the Estonian language by children and adults. ==See also== {{Col-begin}} {{Col-break}} * [http://www.rahvastikuminister.ee Estonian Ministry of Population] * [http://www.meis.ee/eng/raamatukogu Integration Foundation] {{Col-break}} {{col-end}} ==Notes and references== {{reflist}} {{Cultural assimilation|sp=ize}} [[Category:Social history of Estonia]] [[Category:Estonian language| Estonian language]] [[Category:Cultural assimilation]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2011}} {{Notability|1=Organizations|date=July 2010}} {{Infobox European political party |name = Europe United | party_articletitle = Europe United |party_logo = Europe United flag.png | president = [[Bengt Beier]] | founded = {{start date|df=yes|2005}} | dissolved = 2011 | merged = [[European Federalist Party]] | ideology = [[European federalism]]
[[Social liberalism]]
[[Democratization]] | europarl = | colours = Blue and yellow | headquarters = 336 Avenue Georges Henri, 1200 [[Brussels]], Belgium | website = [http://www.europeunited.eu/ Europe United ] }} '''Europe United Party''' was a [[European political party|pan-European]] political party which aimed to achieve a stronger and more accountable [[European Union]] and especially a [[democracy|democratically]] elected [[European Commission]], a more transparent [[European Council]] and a stronger, more representative and effective [[European Parliament]].{{cite web|title=Europe United Party. Introduction|url=http://europeunited.eu/modules/org/item.php?itemid=15|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071007160800/http://europeunited.eu/modules/org/item.php?itemid=15|dead-url=yes|archive-date=7 October 2007|accessdate=21 March 2010}} It was later on incorporated in the [[European Federalist Party]] created on November 6, 2011 in Paris. Europe United was founded as a pro-European organisation in 2005 by [[Finland|Finnish]], but [[Denmark|Danish]]-based politician [[Aki Paasovaara]] shortly after France and the [[Netherlands]] voted down the proposed [[European constitution]]. The party grew fast thanks to engaging its members through an online private social network.In September 2005 Europe United officially registered as a political [[Voluntary association|association]] in [[Denmark]]. The first [[Political convention|convention]] was held in May 2006 at the then-official seat of the organisation in [[Copenhagen]] (Denmark).{{cite web|title=The New Federalist. "Europe United: we need truly pan-European political parties"|url=http://www.thenewfederalist.eu/Europe-United-we-need-truly-pan-European-political-parties|accessdate=21 March 2010}} After the Copenhagen convention, the first election to Europe United's internal policy-making body, the Senate, was held. Tomas Ruta got most votes out of the thirty elected senators. The President and the board of Europe United were [[elections|elected]] by a Convention for a two-year period and functioned as the party's European-level management. Their prime responsibilities were overall strategic leadership and operational leadership of the party's administration and organisational functions. So far, only a limited political program with a focus on democratization of the EU was presented. Agreement on a broad selection of political issues was found at the Convention in [[Leuven]] ([[Belgium]]) in December 2009 and a final vote on the political program of Europe United was planned for the next Convention in [[Salzburg]] ([[Austria]]) in May 2010.{{cite web|title=Europe United Party. Spring Convention 2010 – Salzburg, Austria|url=http://europeunited.eu/modules/community/item.php?itemid=66|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720161708/http://europeunited.eu/modules/community/item.php?itemid=66|dead-url=yes|archive-date=20 July 2011|accessdate=25 March 2010}}{{update inline|date=July 2016}} Europe United presented five [[candidate]]s for the [[European Parliament election, 2009|2009 European Parliament election]] but failed to secure any seats. ==See also== *[[Stand Up For Europe]] *[[Federal Europe]] *[[Pan-European identity]] *[[European political party]] *[[List of political parties]] *[[Pro-Europeanism]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Political organisations at European Union level|state=expanded}} [[Category:Federalist parties]] [[Category:Pan-European political parties]] [[Category:Pro-European political parties]]

{{Cleanup|date=March 2010}} {{no footnotes|date=October 2017}} The '''European Consortium for Political Research''' ('''ECPR''') is an independent scholarly association that supports and encourages the training, research and cross-national cooperation of many thousands of academics and graduate students specialising in political science and all its sub-disciplines. ECPR membership is institutional rather than individual and, at its inception in 1970, comprised eight members ([[University of Bergen|Bergen]], [[University of Gothenburg|Gothenburg]], [[University of Essex|Essex]], [[Leiden University|Leiden]], [[University of Mannheim|Mannheim]], [[Nuffield College]] ([[University of Oxford|Oxford]]), [[University of Strathclyde|Strathclyde]] and [[Fondation Nationale des Sciences Politiques|Paris (FNSP)]]). Membership has now grown to encompass more than 350 institutions throughout [[Europe]], with associate members spread across the world.
;ECPR activities include * Organising workshops, roundtables, conferences and summer schools * Publishing journals, books, articles and newsletters * Providing a comprehensive European information source for political scientists through its website, electronic bulletin and online searchable databases * Promoting teaching and training and the discipline in general through the professional journal [[European Political Science]] (EPS) and summer schools.
The ECPR has close links with similar organisations, such as the [[American Political Science Association]] (APSA), European national associations and the [[International Political Science Association]] (IPSA).
==About==
===[http://ecpr.eu/Filestore/Files/ECPR/ECPR_Constitution.pdf Constitution]=== ===ECPR People=== [http://ecpr.eu/AboutUs/Director.aspx Director] [http://ecpr.eu/AboutUs/ExecutiveCommittee.aspx Executive Committee]
[http://ecpr.eu/AboutUs/CentralServices.aspx Central Services Staff]
==Events== *[http://ecpr.eu/Events/EventTypeDetails.aspx?EventTypeID=2 General conference] *[http://ecpr.eu/Events/EventTypeDetails.aspx?EventTypeID=4 Joint Sessions of Workshops] *[http://ecpr.eu/Events/EventTypeDetails.aspx?EventTypeID=5 Methods School] *[http://ecpr.eu/Events/EventTypeDetails.aspx?EventTypeID=1 Graduate Student Conference] *[http://ecpr.eu/Events/EventTypeDetails.aspx?EventTypeID=6 Research Sessions]
==Funding, Prizes and awards== *[http://ecpr.eu/Prizes/PrizeDetails.aspx?PrizeID=1 Cora Maas Award] *[http://ecpr.eu/Prizes/PrizeDetails.aspx?PrizeID=2 Dirk-Berg-Schlosser Award] *[http://ecpr.eu/Prizes/PrizeDetails.aspx?PrizeID=3 Hans Daalder Prize] *[http://ecpr.eu/Prizes/PrizeDetails.aspx?PrizeID=4 Jean Blondel PhD Prize] *[http://ecpr.eu/Prizes/PrizeDetails.aspx?PrizeID=5 Mattei Dogan Foundation Prize] *[[Stein Rokkan Prize for Comparative Social Science Research]] *[[Rudolf Wildenmann Prize]] *[http://ecpr.eu/Prizes/PrizeDetails.aspx?PrizeID=8 ECPR Lifetime Achievement Award] *[https://ecpr.eu/Prizes/PrizeDetails.aspx?PrizeID=9 Joni Lovenduski PhD Prize in Gender and Politics] *[http://ecpr.eu/Prizes/PrizeDetails.aspx?PrizeID=10 EPS Prize] *[https://ecpr.eu/Prizes/PrizeDetails.aspx?PrizeID=11 Hedley Bull Prize in International Relations]
==Publications==
The following academic journals are published by ECPR, in conjunction with other academic publishers: *[[European Journal of Political Research]] (EJPR), with Wiley-Blackwell *[[European Political Science Review]] (EPSR), with Cambridge University Press *[[European Political Science]] (EPS), with Palgrave Macmillan
==ECPR Press== [http://press.ecpr.eu/ ECPR Press] publishes original research across all fields of political science, international relations and political thought, without restriction in approach or regional focus. It is also open to interdisciplinary work with a predominant political dimension. The Press has four main series: Studies in European Political Research, Monographs, Classics, and Essays.
==Standing Groups and Research Networks== ECPR [http://ecpr.eu/StandingGroups/GeneralInfo.aspx Standing Groups] encourage collaboration between scholars specialising in the same area of research. Their informal structure allows closer exchange of ideas.
Standing groups are open to individuals in ECPR member institutions as well as those from non-ECPR institutions.

'''File integrity monitoring (FIM)''' is an [[internal control]] or [[process (computing)|process]] that performs the act of validating the [[integrity]] of [[operating system]] and [[application software]] [[Computer file|files]] using a verification method between the current file state and a known, good [[baseline (configuration management)|baseline]]. This comparison method often involves calculating a known cryptographic [[checksum]] of the file's original baseline and comparing with the calculated checksum of the current state of the file.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ionx.co.uk/products/verisys/how-it-works |title= Verisys - How it Works |publisher= Ionx|accessdate=2012-09-21}}</ref> Other file attributes can also be used to monitor integrity.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ncircle.com/index.php?s=products_ccm_file-integrity-monitoring|title=File Integrity Monitoring|publisher=nCircle|accessdate=2012-04-18}}</ref>
Generally, the act of performing file integrity monitoring is automated using internal controls such as an application or [[process (computing)|process]]. Such monitoring can be performed [[Randomness|randomly]], at a defined [[polling (computer science)|polling]] interval, or in [[Real-time computing|real-time]].
==Security objectives== Changes to configurations, files and file attributes across the IT infrastructure are common, but hidden within a large volume of daily changes can be the few that impact file or configuration integrity. These changes can also reduce security posture and in some cases may be leading indicators of a breach in progress. Values monitored for unexpected changes to files or configuration items include: * Credentials * Privileges and Security Settings * Content * Core attributes and size * Hash values * Configuration values
==Compliance objectives== Multiple [[Regulatory compliance|compliance objectives]] indicate file integrity monitoring as a [[requirement]]. Several examples of compliance objectives with the requirement for file integrity monitoring include: * [[Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard|PCI-DSS - Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard]] (Requirement 11.5)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pcisecuritystandards.org/documents/pa-dss_v2.pdf|title=Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard|publisher=PCI Security Council |accessdate= 2011-10-11}}</ref> * [[Sarbanes-Oxley Act|SOX - Sarbanes-Oxley Act]] (Section 404)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/rules/proposed/s74002/card941503.pdf|title=Sarbanes-Oxley Sections 302 & 404 - A White Paper Proposing Practival, Cost Effective Compliance Strategies|publisher=Card Decisions, Inc.|accessdate= 2011-10-11}}</ref> * [[North American Electric Reliability Corporation|NERC CIP]] - NERC CIP Standard (CIP-010-2)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nerc.com/_layouts/PrintStandard.aspx?standardnumber=CIP-010-2&title=Cyber%20Security%20-%20Configuration%20Change%20Management%20and%20Vulnerability%20Assessments&jurisdiction=null|title=Standard CIP-010-2 - Security Configuration, Change Management and Vulnerability Assessments |publisher=North American Electric Reliability Corporation (NERC)|accessdate= 2016-06-06}}</ref> * [[Federal Information Security Management Act of 2002|FISMA - Federal Information Security Management Act]] (NIST SP800-53 Rev3)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://csrc.nist.gov/groups/SMA/fisma/ics/documents/papers/Apply-SP-800-53-ICS-final-22Aug06.pdf|title=Applying NIST SP 800-53 to Industrial Control Systems|publisher=National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)|accessdate= 2011-10-11}}</ref> * [[Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act|HIPAA - Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996]] (NIST Publication 800-66)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://csrc.nist.gov/publications/nistpubs/800-66-Rev1/SP-800-66-Revision1.pdf|title=An Introductory Resource Guide for Implementing the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) Security Rule|publisher=National Institute of Standards and Technology|accessdate= 2011-10-11}}</ref> * [[20 Critical Security Controls|SANS Critical Security Controls]] (Control 3)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sans.org/critical-security-controls/control.php?id=3|title=Critical Control 3: Secure Configurations for Hardware and Software on Mobile Devices, Laptops, Workstations, and Servers|publisher=SANS Institute|accessdate=2012-11-19}}</ref>
==Applications== Some examples include: * [https://www.manageengine.com/data-security/ ManageEngine]<ref>https://www.manageengine.com/data-security/</ref> * [[Advanced Intrusion Detection Environment]] * [[CimTrak]] * [[CloudPassage]] * [[LogRhythm]] * [[McAfee Change Control]] * [[OSSEC]] * [[Qualys]] * [[Samhain (software)|Samhain]] * [[Splunk]] * [[System File Checker]] (provided with Windows) * [[Trend Micro]] Deep Security * [[Tripwire (company)|Tripwire]] products * [[Trustwave Holdings|Trustwave]] * [[Verisys]]
==References==

revision.text:
{{Infobox country |conventional_long_name= Free City of Danzig Government in Exile |native_name = |image_flag = Flag of the Free City of Danzig.svg |image_coat = |common_name = Free State of Danzig |symbol_type = |motto = ''"[[Nec Temere, Nec Timide]]"'' |national_anthem = |status = Unrecognized state |sovereignty_type = [[Government-in-exile]] |image_map = File:Claims of the Free City of Danzig in Exile.svg |map_caption = Territory claimed by the Free State of Danzig (map of modern-day Europe) |capital = [[Berlin]], [[Germany]] (capital-in-exile) | largest_city = |official_languages = [[German language|German]] |government_type = [[Parliamentary system]] |leader_title1 = President of the Senate |leader_name1 = Beowulf von Prince |leader_title2 = Head of Foreign Affairs (Senator) |leader_name2 = Ernst F. Kriesner |legislature = Rat der Danziger |established_event1 = Proclaimed |established_date1 = 13 November 1947 |area_km2 = 1,966 |area_sq_mi = 759 |population_estimate = |currency = |time_zone = |calling_code = |footnotes = |micronation = |nummembers = }} The '''Free City of Danzig Government in Exile''' or the '''Free State of Danzig''', is a self-declared [[government in exile]] which claims sovereignty over the territory of the defunct [[Free City of Danzig]].
== Background == [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 146-1996-030-01A, Danzig, Flüchtlingstreck.jpg|thumb|225px|German refugees leaving Danzig, February 1945|left]] The Free City of Danzig ({{lang-de|Freie Stadt Danzig}}; {{lang-pl|Wolne Miasto Gdańsk}}) was a semi-[[autonomous]] [[city-state]] that existed between 1920 and 1939, consisting of the [[Baltic Sea]] port of Danzig (now [[Gdańsk]], [[Poland]]) and nearly 200 towns in the surrounding areas. It was created on 15 November 1920<ref>{{cite book| title = Danzig – Biographie einer Stadt| url = https://books.google.com/?id=9ifeo6zdSMcC| date = February 2011| publisher = C.H. Beck| language = German| isbn = 978-3-406-60587-1| page = 189| last1 = Loew| first1 = Peter Oliver| authorlink1 = Peter Oliver Loew }}</ref><ref>{{cite book| title = Das Bistum Danzig in Lebensbildern| url = https://books.google.com/?id=VMvgZQrdkxcC| year = 2003| publisher = LIT Verlag| language = German| isbn = 3-8258-6284-4| page = 8| last1 = Samerski| first1 = Stefan }}</ref> in accordance with the 1919 [[Treaty of Versailles]] after the end of [[World War I]] and was under [[League of Nations]] protection. The Free City was primarily inhabited by ethnic Germans but the majority [[Flight and expulsion of Germans from Poland during and after World War II|fled or were expelled]] when the territory was incorporated into Poland at the conclusion of [[World War II]].
== History == On 13 November 1947, W. Richter, the chairman of the Association of Nationals of Danzig Free State, announced the formation of a government-in-exile for the Free City of Danzig.<ref name= sydney/> The government made pleas to the [[United Nations]], calling for official recognition, the deportation of Poles from its claimed territory, and assistance in reestablishing the Free City.<ref name= Schoenburg/> Richter also announced that the association would accept a settlement from the international community that would grant them an alternative territory in a center of commerce.<ref name= sydney>{{cite news| date = 14 November 1947| title = Move For New Danzig Territory| url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1301&dat=19471115&id=CBhVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=yZMDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2558,1793699| newspaper = [[The Sydney Morning Herald]]| location = [[London]]| access-date = 6 November 2016}}</ref> The legislative body of the government in exile, the ''Rat der Danziger'' (Council of Danzig), was established that year. In 1951 and 1961, it was supposedly recognized in secret by Danzig expatriates as the "legal successor of the [[Senate]] of the Free City of Danzig."<ref>{{cite magazine| date = 4 April 1967| title = An Inez denken| url = http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-45293081.html| magazine = [[Der Spiegel]]| location = [[Gdańsk]], [[Poland]]|language= German | access-date= 6 November 2016}}</ref>
== Government == The Free State of Danzig government is based in [[Berlin]], [[Germany]]. It respects the original Constitution of the Free City of Danzig.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://hoheit.worldcitizenship.info/standard/downloads/deutsch/Regierungserklaerung.pdf| title = Regierungserklärung| last = von Prince| first = Beowulf | date = 17 March 2010| publisher =|language = German}}</ref> The official government website is run by the incumbent Head of Foreign Affairs, Senator Ernst F. Kriesner.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.danzigfreestate.org/| title = Free State of Danzig: Government-in-Exile| last = Kriesner| first = Ernst F.| website = Free State of Danzig| access-date =6 November 2016}}</ref> The government's legislature takes the form of a parliament, the ''Rat der Danziger'' (Council of Danzig), which has 36 members<ref>{{cite book| editor-last = Messenger| editor-first = David A.| editor-last2 = Paehler| editor-first2 = Katrin| title = A Nazi Past: Recasting German Identity in Postwar Europe| publisher = University Press of Kentucky| date = 2015| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=CzXKBwAAQBAJ&dq=| isbn = 9780813160580 | quote = [...]'Rat der Danzig,' the freely elected council of thirty-six delegates that regarded itself as the parliament of the Free City of Danzig in exile.}}</ref> and claims to represent the interests of German Danzigers.<ref>{{cite book| last = Kuhn| first = Ekkehard | title = Flucht Vertreibung Integration: Über das Schicksal der Deutschen nach dem Zweiten Weltkrieg| publisher = BoD – Books on Demand| date = 2016| pages = 126| language = German| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Hw0ADAAAQBAJ&dq=| isbn = 9783839136461}}</ref> Members of the council are elected by Danzig expatriates and their descendants by a mailed-in ballot.<ref>{{cite book| last = Loew| first = Peter Oliver| title = Danzig: Biographie einer Stadt | publisher = C.H.Beck | date = 2011| location = [[Gdańsk]], [[Poland]]| pages = 250| language = German| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=9ifeo6zdSMcC&dq=| isbn = 9783406605871}}</ref>
=== Recognition and relations === A formal letter was sent to the United Nations in 1998 by Senator Kriesner requesting official recognition.<ref name= application>{{cite web| url = http://www.danzigfreestate.org/unmembership.html| title = Application for UN Membership| last = Kriesner| first = Ernst F.| website = Free State of Danzig| access-date = 6 November 2016}}</ref>
Writing on the lack of official German recognition of the Free City of Danzig Government in Exile, [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Poland)|Polish Foreign Minister]] [[Władysław Bartoszewski]] stated that the organization and like-minded Danzig cultural associations were seen in the eyes of the German public as [[Revanchism|revanchist]] and politically aligned with the far-right [[National Democratic Party of Germany]].<ref>{{Citation| last = Bartoszewski| first = Władysław| author-link = Władysław Bartoszewski| date = 7 February 2001| title = Odpowiedź ministra spraw zagranicznych na zapytanie nr 2981| language = Polish | publisher = [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Poland)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]]| publication-place = [[Warsaw, Poland]]| url = http://orka2.sejm.gov.pl/IZ3.nsf/main/748E6134| accessdate = 7 November 2016}}</ref>
=== Claims === The government lays claims to the entire territory once possessed by the Free City of Danzig.<ref name= Schoenburg>{{cite book| last = Schoenburg| first = H. W.| title = Germans from the East: A Study of Their Migration, Resettlement and Subsequent Group History, Since 1945 | publisher = Springer Science & Business Media | series = Studies in Social Life| edition = illustrated| date = 2012| pages = 186| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=UVEBCAAAQBAJ&dq=| isbn = 9789401032452}}</ref> It bases the legitimacy of its assertion upon the notion that the Free City of Danzig was a neutral state and that its [[Reichsgau Danzig-West Prussia|annexation]] by Germany in 1939 was illegal; as such, the [[Allies of World War II|Allies]] had no authority in incorporating the city into Poland after World War II.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.danzigfreestate.org/danzig-stiftung.htm| title = Iustitia Omnibus Gedanum- Fair Justice for Danzig: Danzig People have Human Rights also!| website = Free State of Danzig| access-date = 6 November 2016}}</ref> In addition to this, no formal treaty has ever altered the status of the Free City of Danzig, and its incorporation into Poland has rested upon the general acquiescence of the international community.<ref>{{cite book| last = Capps| first = Patrick| last2 = Evans| first2 = Malcolm David| title = Asserting Jurisdiction: International and European Legal Perspectives| publisher = Hart Publishing| date = 2003| pages = 25| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=bb0VULJ8g5MC&dq=| isbn = 9781841133058}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.danzigfreestate.org/ Free State of Danzig (official website)] * [http://www.danzigfreestate.org/unmembership.html Application for UN Membership] * [http://freistaat-danzig.com/ Official website campaign for UN Membership] * [https://ratderdanziger.info/ EXEKUTIVORGAN DES RATES DER DANZIGER (official Council website)] * [https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCXXjp735xcW5lRkSM56le_A Official Council YouTube channel] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20160927200855/https://wahlausschuss.info/ 2016 Council elections website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20170205101548/https://ratderdanziger.info/2016-09-04%20Leitpolitik%20des%20Rates%20der%20Danziger%20-%20Basic%20Politics%20of%20the%20Danzig%20Council.pdf LEITPOLITIK DES RATES DER DANZIGER/BASIC POLITICS OF THE DANZIG COUNCIL] * [http://hoheit.worldcitizenship.info/standard/downloads/deutsch/2-Steuergesetz-vom-26-08-2015.pdf Official taxation law]

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{about|Iranian protests against compulsory hijab in 2017–18|the protests against Iranian regime|2017–18 Iranian protests}} {{Infobox civil conflict |title = Girls of Enghelab Street |image = [[File:Girl of Enghelab Street.jpg|260px]] |caption = An Iranian woman showing support for the Girls of Enghelab Street in Hauptplatz in [[Linz]] |date = Since {{Start date|2017|12|28|df=yes}} |place = [[Iran]] |partof = [[2017–18 Iranian protests]] |goals = Removal of Compulsory Hijab law |arrests = At least 40<ref>https://www.radiofarda.com/a/arrest-of--a-protester-to-the-forced-veil/29570536.html</ref> |side1 = {{flagicon image|White Wednesday Movement.jpg}} Protesters |side2 = {{Unbulleted list|{{flagicon|Iran}} [[Government of Islamic Republic of Iran|Islamic Republic]]|{{*}}[[Law Enforcement Force of the Islamic Republic of Iran|Police]]}} |subtitle = |methods = {{unbulleted list|[[Civil disobedience]]|[[Nonviolent resistance]]}} }} '''Girls of Enghelab Street''' ([[Persian language|Persian]]: دختران خیابان انقلاب) is a series of protests against [[Hijab by country#Iran|compulsory hijab]] in Iran. The protests were inspired by '''Vida Movahed''' ({{lang-fa|ویدا موحد}}), an Iranian woman known as the '''Girl of Enghelab Street''' ({{lang-fa|دختر خیابان انقلاب}}), who stood in the crowd on a utility box in the [[Enqelab Street|Enghelab Street]] (Revolution Street) of [[Tehran]] on 28 December 2017, tied her hijab, a white headscarf, to a stick, and waved it to the crowd as a flag.<ref name="al-monitor.com_1"/><ref name="albawaba.com_1"/><ref name="dailystar.com.lb_1"/><ref name="foxnews.com_1"/> She was arrested on that day<ref name="dailystar.com.lb_1"/><ref name="foxnews.com_1"/> and was released temporary on bail<ref name="iranhumanrights.org_1"/><ref name="newyorker.com_1"/> a month later, on 28 January 2018.<ref name="NasrinSotoudeh_1"/><ref name="independent.co.uk_1"/> Some people believe that Movahed's action was based on [[Masih Alinejad]]'s call for [[White Wednesdays]], a protest movement that the presenter at [[VOA-PNN|VOA Persian Television]] started in early 2017.<ref name="globalvoices.org_1"/><ref name="theguardian.com_1"/><ref name="rferl.org_2"/> Other women later re-enacted her protest and posted photos of their actions on social media. These women are described as the "Girls of Enghelab Street"<ref name="theguardian.com_1"/> and "The Girls Of Revolution Street"<ref>https://www.voanews.com/a/in-tehran-new-hijab-protester-led-off-by-police/4635838.html</ref> in English sources. Some of the protesters claim that they didn't follow Masih Alinejad's call.<ref name="en.radiofarda.com_2"/><ref name="radiozamaneh.com_1"/><ref name="radiozamaneh.com_1"/><ref name="asriran.com_1"/><ref name="tasnimnews.com_1"/>
== Islamic Republic's Penal Code == {{see|Theocracy#Iran}} In the Islamic law of Iran imposed shortly after the [[Iranian Revolution|1979 Islamic revolution]], article 638 of 5th book of Islamic Penal Code (called Sanctions and deterrent penalties) women who do not wear a hijab may be imprisoned from ten days to two months, and/or required to pay fines from 50,000 up to 500,000 [[Iranian rial|rials]].<ref name="thesun.co.uk_1"/><ref name="article_638_iran_law"/> Fines are recalculated in the courts as the value of Iranian rials drops every year since 1979.
Article 639 of the same book says, two type of people shall be sentenced to one year to 10 years imprisonment, first a person who establishes or directs a place of immorality or prostitution, second a person who facilitates or encourages people to commit immorality or prostitution.<ref name="iranhumanrights.org_2"/><ref name="article_639_iran_law"/>
These are some of the laws under which some protesters were charged.<ref name="iranhumanrights.org_2"/><ref name="rudaw.net_1"/>
== Background == Before the [[Iranian Islamic Revolution]] of 1979 (during the reign of [[Mohammad Reza Pahlavi]], the last [[Shah]] of Iran) the hijab was not compulsory,<ref name="El Guindi"/> though some Iranian women during this period wore headscarfs or [[chador]].<ref name="Abrahamian"/>
After the 1979 Islamic revolution, the hijab gradually became compulsory.<ref name="Milani"/> In 1979, [[Ruhollah Khomeini]] announced that women should observe Islamic dress code;<ref name="Milani"/><ref name=Algar84/> His statement sparked demonstrations, which were met by government assurances that the statement was only a recommendation.<ref name="Milani"/><ref name=Algar84/> Hijab was subsequently made mandatory in government and public offices in 1980, and in 1983 it became mandatory for all women.<ref name="Milani"/>
In 2018, a government run survey dating back to 2014, was released by President [[Hassan Rouhani]], showing that 49.8% of Iranians were against compulsory or mandatory hijab.<ref name="nytimes.com_1"/><ref name="post-gazette.com_1"/> The report was released by the [[Center for Strategic Studies]], the research arm of the Iranian President's office, and was titled "Report of the first hijab special meeting" on July 2014 in a PDF format.<ref name="css.ir_1"/>
On 2 February 2018 a poll conducted by the Center for International and Security Studies at Maryland (CISSM) showed that a few Iranians agreed with "changing Iran's political system or relaxing strict Islamic law".<ref name="washingtonpost">{{cite web|last1=Taylor|first1=Adam|title=Most Iranians feel Trump’s comments in support of protesters didn’t help, poll finds|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2018/02/02/most-iranians-feel-trumps-comments-in-support-of-protesters-didnt-help-poll-finds/|website=washingtonpost|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
Iran is the only country in the world that requires non-Muslim women to wear a headscarf.<ref name="firstpost.com_1"/> For example, in January 2018, a [[Chinese people|Chinese]] female musician was forcibly veiled in the middle of her concert performance.<ref>https://www.albawaba.com/loop/chinese-musician-humiliated-iran-hijab-imposed-mid-performance-1074470</ref>
== Timeline == === December 2017 === ==== 28 December ==== On 28 December 2017, pictures and videos of Movahed waving her scarf went viral through the hashtag "Where_is_she?" ({{lang|fa|#دختر_خیابان_انقلاب_کجاست}}, "Where is the girl of Enghelab Street" in Persian) on social media. While at first she was unknown, days later, [[Nasrin Sotoudeh]], the human rights activist and lawyer who has also been arrested, found out that the girl is 31 years old and was arrested on the spot with her 19-month-old baby.<ref name="al-monitor.com_1"/><ref name="albawaba.com_1"/><ref name="dailystar.com.lb_1"/>
=== January 2018 === ==== 28 January ==== On 28 January 2018, according to Nasrin Sotoudeh, the lawyer investigating the case, Vida Movahed was released;<ref name="NasrinSotoudeh_1"/><ref name="independent.co.uk_1"/> temporary on bail.<ref name="iranhumanrights.org_1"/><ref name="newyorker.com_1"/>
==== 29 January ==== On 29 January 2018, a woman was arrested in Tehran after re-enacting Movahed's protest by standing on the same utility box in Enqelab Street, taking off her white Hijab, and holding it up on a stick. Photos has been posted on social media show that at least three other women re-enacted Movahed's protest in Tehran on 29 January, including one near [[Ferdowsi Street|Ferdowsi Square]].<ref name="theguardian.com_1"/>
==== 30 January ==== According to Nasrin Sotoudeh on 30 January 2018, the second woman who was arrested on 29 January 2018 was '''Narges Hosseini''' ({{lang-fa|نرگس حسینی}}); her age is 32.<ref name="straitstimes.com_1"/>
On 30 January 2018, several more women, but also men, protested against the compulsory hijab law by re-enacting Movahed's protest.<ref name="rferl.org_2"/><ref name="globalvoices.org_1"/> This took place in Tehran, as well as other cities as well including [[Isfahan|Esfahan]] and [[Shiraz]].<ref name="iranhumanrights.org_2"/><ref name="aljazeera.com_1"/>
=== February 2018 === ==== 1 February ==== On 1st February 2018 the Iranian Police department announced they had arrested 29 women for taking off their hijab.<ref name="ibtimes.co.uk_1"/><ref name="rferl.org_3"/><ref name="theguardian.com_2"/><ref name="aljazeera.com_1"/>
==== 2 February ==== According to Nasrin Sotoudeh, the Iranian lawyer, Narges Hosseini known as the second girl of Enghelab street, who is 32 years old was unable to pay the $135,000 USD bail set by the judge presiding over her case, facing a possible 10 years in prison and up to 74 lashes on charges including openly committing a sinful act.<ref name="iranhumanrights.org_2"/><ref name="rudaw.net_1"/>
{{see|#Islamic Penal Code}}
==== 15 February ==== New photos and video shared on social media shows another woman re-enacting Movahed's protest on the same street, Enghelab Street (Revolution Street) on 15 February 2018 was identified as '''Azam Jangravi''' ({{lang-fa|اعظم جنگروی}}), videos shows that the police took her down aggressively. According to her latest Instagram picture, she said that she a part of [[Iranian Reformists|Iranian women Reformists]] and [[Executives of Construction Party]] and has taken no orders from neither someone from inside nor outside the country, she said she has done that to protest against compulsory hijab.<ref name="en.radiofarda.com_2"/><ref name="hrw.org_1"/><ref name="radiozamaneh.com_2"/>
==== 17 February ==== Narges Hosseini and Azam Jangravi were released from the custody temporary on bail.<ref name="hrw.org_1"/>
==== 21 February ==== Another female protester named '''Shaparak Shajarizadeh''' ({{lang-fa|شاپرک شجری زاده}}) was arrested protesting with a white scarf on Wednesday, 21 February 2018 in [[Gheytarieh]] street; eyewitnesses said that the police attacked her from behind and took her in custody.<ref name="en.radiofarda.com_3"/><ref name="hrw.org_1"/><ref name="radiozamaneh.com_3"/>
[[File:Vesal-Enghelab-2018-02-24 21-23-09.jpg|thumb|250px|The original utility box that Vida Movahed and other protesters stood on top of, located in the Enghelab–Vesal Junction in Tehran. It has since been altered by the government to prevent protesters from standing on its top.]]
Photos shared on social media shows that the government was placing an inverted v-shaped iron structure on the utility boxes so as to inhibit anyone standing on top of the boxes.<ref name="radiozamaneh.com_4"/> She was sentenced to two years in prison in addition to an 18-year suspended prison term.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Iranian woman gets 20-year punishment for publicly taking off hijab|url=https://stepfeed.com/iranian-woman-gets-20-year-punishment-for-publicly-taking-off-hijab-9989|website=StepFeed.com|date=July 10, 2018}}</ref> In addition, she stated that she left [[Iran]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Iranian Woman Who Protested Hijab Rule Gets Two-Year Sentence, Leaves Country|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/iranian-woman-hijab-protest-two-year-sentence/29354892.html|publisher=[[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]]|date=July 10, 2018}}</ref>
==== 22 February ==== Another woman named '''Maryam Shariatmadari''' ({{lang-fa|مریم شریعتمداری}}) was protesting compulsory hijab in the afternoon on a utility box; the police asked her to come down and the woman refused and questioned the police what's her crime, "disturbing the peace" the police replied. Then, as she was violently ejected by the police, she was injured and her leg was broken.<ref name="en.radiofarda.com_3"/><ref name="radiozamaneh.com_5"/>
Shaparak Shajarizadeh was beaten up in custody.<ref name="en.radiofarda.com_3"/> She was released later temporary on bail.<ref name="en.radiofarda.com_3"/>
==== 24 February ==== Eyewitnesses said that another women named '''Hamraz Sadeghi''' ({{lang-fa|همراز صادقی}}) was protesting compulsory hijab on Saturday, 24 February 2018 when suddenly she was attacked by an unknown security force, her arm was broken and was arrested.<ref name="radiofarda.com_1"/>
=== July 2018 === ==== 8 July ==== On July 8, 2018, Iranian teenager Maedeh Hojabri was arrested after she posted videos of herself dancing to Western and Iranian music on her [[Instagram]] account without her headscarf.<ref name="The Guardian">{{Cite web|title=Woman arrested in Iran for Instagram video of her dancing|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jul/08/iran-woman-arrested-instagram-video-dancing|date=July 8, 2018}}</ref> She was among several [[List of most-followed Instagram accounts|popular Instagram users]], with more than 600,000 followers.<ref name="The Guardian"/> Her videos were shared by hundreds of people.<ref name="The Guardian"/> Several Iranian women posted videos of themselves dancing to protest her arrest.<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Barron|first1=Laignee|title=Women in Iran Are Dancing to Protest the Arrest of a Teenage Instagrammer|url=http://time.com/5332944/iran-arrest-teenage-dancer-maedeh-hojabri/|magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=July 9, 2018}}</ref>
=== October 2018 === ==== 27 October ==== On 27 October 2018, students in [[Islamic Azad University, Central Tehran Branch]] protested after a morality police van entered the campus and attempted to arrest several women for improper hijab. Videos showed a student standing in front of the van, attempting to block its exit, which lead to the driver of the van attempting to run her over.<ref>https://ir.voanews.com/a/iran-police-hijab/4632492.html</ref>
==== 29 October ==== On 29 October 2018, an Iranian woman stood on the dome of Enghelab square in [[Tehran]], and removed her headscarf in protest to the compulsory hijab. She was arrested minutes later by the police.<ref>https://www.radiofarda.com/a/arrest-of--a-protester-to-the-forced-veil/29570536.html</ref>
== Reactions == === National === * Iranian chief prosecutor – [[Mohammad Jafar Montazeri]] on 31 January 2018, reacted to the protests by calling them "trivial" and "childish" moves that were incited by foreigners.<ref name="sputniknews.com_1"/> * The deputy speaker of parliament – [[Ali Motahari]], on 31 January 2018 said that there is no compulsory hijab in Iran, since women show up wearing whatever they like.<ref name="thenational.ae_1"/><ref name="al-monitor.com_2"/><ref name="timesofindia.indiatimes.com_1"/><ref name="dawn.com_1"/> * A member of the parliament – [[Soheila Jolodarzadeh]] Iranian politician on 31 January 2018 said that the protests is the result of their unnecessary restriction for women.<ref name="theguardian.com_2"/> * [[Judicial system of Iran|Judiciary]] – Iraninan judiciary spokesman, [[Gholam-Hossein Mohseni-Eje'i]] on 4 February 2018 said, some of the arrested women were on "synthetic drugs"; he also declared that if it is proven their protests were organized, their crime will be much heavier.<ref name="iranhumanrights.org_2"/> * President [[Hassan Rouhani]] on 11 February 2018, 39th anniversary of Islamic Revolution said under the article 59 of the constitution any conflicts in Iranian society could be resolved with a constitutional referendum.<ref name="nytimes.com_2"/> * Iranian senior actress and director – [[Marzieh Boroumand]] on 14 February 2018 said that she is against compulsory hijab but she is not supporting Masih Alinejad's lead on the movement, she said that Alinejad is trying to seize every movement inside the country to her own and gives excuses to the government that the protesters are getting orders from her and making trouble for young people.<ref name="radiozamaneh.com_1"/><ref name="asriran.com_1"/><ref name="tasnimnews.com_1"/> * City Council of Tehran – [[Nahid Khodakarami]], an Iranian midwife and a member of [[City Council of Tehran]] on 15 February 2018 said that choosing their own clothes is the least right that women can have, "Which one is has more sin, hairs of Azam Jangravi or that man's hand?" said Ms. Khodakarami is reaction to the video of arresting Azam Jangravi.<ref name="fa.euronews.com_1"/><ref name="twitter.com_1"/><ref name="twitter.com_2"/> * An academic – "Who and based on what article of the law allowed to the police to eject that women like that?", said [[Abdollah Ramezanzadeh]] on 22 February 2018.<ref name="AbdollahRamezanzadeh_1"/> [[File:Mehdi Tabatabaei 1393.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Seyyed Mehdi Tabatabaei]], Iranian Shia cleric said that forcing hijab on people is against Islam and has a reverse result.<ref name="jamaran.ir_1"/>]] * An Iranian Shia cleri – [[Seyyed Mehdi Tabatabaei]] on 22 February 2018 in reaction to the arrests said that for sure hijab is requirement in Islam, no doubt, but does that mean shouble force it on people?.<ref name="jamaran.ir_1"/> * [[Law Enforcement Force of the Islamic Republic of Iran|Iranian police]] – on 23 February 2018 has officially warned if someone take their hijabs off, they will be imprisoned up to 10 years according to the article 639 of the law. Police said that it is their job to make sure that someone is not breaking the law.<ref name="farsnews.com_1"/> {{see|#Islamic Penal Code}} * An Iranian journalist – The Ghanoon (The Law) Newspaper has published an article on 24 February 2018 on the main page written by Mehrshad Imani, let's not call the hijabless people, prostitutes based on article 639 of the law.<ref name="bbc.com_1"/>
=== International === * [[Amnesty International]] on 24 January 2018 called on the Iranian government to free the arrested woman unconditionally.<ref name="rferl.org_1"/> On 2 February 2018 Amnesty International once again calls on the government to release six human right defenders including one of the protesters Shima Babaei who were arrested on 1 February 2018 .<ref name="amnesty.org_1"/><ref name="en.radiofarda.com_1"/><ref name="ekklesia.co.uk_1"/> * {{flagu|United States}} – [[Heather Nauert]], spokeswoman of the [[United States Department of State]] on 2 February 2018 said that United States condemns the arrests of people who are protesting against compulsory hijab law, and United States supports those people.<ref name="state.gov_1"/><ref name="straitstimes.com_2"/><ref name="rferl.org_4"/><ref name="uniindia.com_1"/><ref name="pakistantoday.com.pk_1"/><ref name="egypttoday.com_1"/> * Women from Around the World – On 6 February 2018, campaign on social media with the hashtag #NoHijabDay raises, where other women from around the world burn their hijabs in solidarity with Iranian women who are forced to wear hijab.<ref name="mirror.co.uk_1"/><ref name="stepfeed.com_1"/> * The director of the Middle East Program at [[Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars|Wilson Center]] – [[Haleh Esfandiari]] an Iranian-born American based in Washington, on 17 February 2018 in an interview with [[Axios (website)|Axios]] said her opinion is that these protests are causing a stir but they are not a movement yet.<ref name="axios.com_1"/> * [[Human Rights Watch]] – [[Sarah Leah Whitson]] the Middle East director of HRW on 24 February 2018 asked the Iranian government to drop the charges against the protesters.<ref name="hrw.org_1"/><ref name="en.radiofarda.com_3"/> * 45 [[Member of the European Parliament|Members of the European Parliament]] on 28 February 2018 call on EU Foreign Policy Chief [[Federica Mogherini]] to support the
