The '''trial of [[Geert Wilders]]''', a member of the [[House of Representatives of the Netherlands]], took place in the [[Netherlands]] in 2010 and 2011. Wilders was accused of criminally insulting religious and ethnic groups and [[Incitement to ethnic or racial hatred|inciting hatred]] and [[Religious discrimination|discrimination]]. He was found not guilty in June 2011.<ref name="acquitted1">{{cite web |url=http://www.nrc.nl/nieuws/2011/06/23/wilders-vrijgesproken-van-groepsbelediging/ |title=Wilders op alle punten vrijgesproken |last=Hinke |first=Bart |date=23 June 2011 |work=[[NRC Handelsblad]] |language=Dutch |accessdate=23 June 2011}}</ref>
The leader of the [[Party for Freedom]], Wilders has been the source of great controversy in the Netherlands and abroad for his [[criticism of Islam]] and what he describes as the [[Islamization]] of the Netherlands. At his trial, he faced five counts of criminal offenses. The first charge was of criminally insulting Muslims because of their religion. The remaining four charges pertained to incitement of hatred and discrimination of Muslims, [[Moroccan people|Moroccans]], and other non-[[Western world|Western]] immigrants because of their race or ethnicity. These charges stemmed from articles Wilders had written between 2006 and 2008, as well as his short film ''[[Fitna (film)|Fitna]]''. These statements included a call for a ban on the [[Quran]],<ref>{{cite news |title=Wilders: verbied de Koran, ook in moskee |url=http://www.volkskrant.nl/binnenland/article451302.ece/Wilders_verbied_de_Koran%2C_ook_in_moskee |language=Dutch |work=[[de Volkskrant]] |date=8 August 2007 |accessdate=8 August 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Genoeg is genoeg: verbied de Koran |url=http://www.volkskrant.nl/binnenland/article451338.ece/Genoeg_is_genoeg_verbied_de_Koran |work=[[de Volkskrant]] |date=8 August 2007 |first=Geert |last=Wilders |authorlink=Geert Wilders |accessdate=24 March 2008 |language=Dutch}}</ref> warnings against an "Islamic [[invasion]],"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pvv.nl/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=352&Itemid=6 |title=Mohammed deel II: de islamitische invasie |work=[[Party for Freedom]] |accessdate=24 June 2011}}</ref> and a "tsunami of Islamization."<ref>{{cite news |title=Wilders bang voor 'tsunami van islamisering' |url=http://www.volkskrant.nl/vk/nl/2686/Binnenland/article/detail/786026/2006/10/06/Wilders-bang-voor-tsunami-van-islamisering.dhtml |newspaper=[[de Volkskrant]] |date=6 October 2006 |accessdate=6 July 2012}}</ref> He also labeled Islam a [[Fascism|fascist]] religion, described Dutch-[[Morocco|Moroccan]] youths as violent, and compared the Quran with [[Adolf Hitler|Hitler]]'s ''[[Mein Kampf]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.radionetherlands.nl/currentaffairs/ned070808mc |title='Qur'an should be banned' – Wilders strikes again |publisher=[[Radio Netherlands]] |date=8 January 2007 |accessdate=24 March 2008 |first=Nicolien |last=den Boer |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080315004643/http://www.radionetherlands.nl/currentaffairs/ned070808mc |archivedate=15 March 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> He has also referred to [[Mohammed]] as "the [[devil]]."<ref>{{cite web |last=Cunningham |first=Benjamin |title=Islam opponent to visit Prague |url=http://www.praguepost.com/news/2905-islam-opponent-to-visit-prague.html |work=[[The Prague Post]] |accessdate=4 June 2011 |date=25 November 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=De profeet Mohammed is een enge duivel |url=http://www.nieuwsblad.be/Article/Detail.aspx?ArticleID=B11NPCFS |publisher=[[Het Nieuwsblad]] |accessdate=4 June 2011 |date=9 February 2008}}</ref>
The judges in the first trial were [[Judicial disqualification|removed]] due to perceived [[bias]] against Wilders,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-11609589 |title=Judges told to step down in Wilders trial |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=22 October 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref> so a [[New trial|retrial]] began in February 2011. The Dutch [[Openbaar Ministerie|Public Prosecution Service]], after initially refusing to prosecute Wilders because it did not consider his statements illegal, was ordered by a court of appeal to prosecute him nonetheless. During the process, they argued that Wilders should be acquitted on all counts.<ref name=OM1>{{cite web |url=http://www.om.nl/actueel-0/strafzaken/strafzaak_tegen/@154305/public_prosecution_0/ |title=Public Prosecution Service requests acquittal for all counts in Wilders case |accessdate=27 May 2011 |date=15 October 2010 |publisher=[[Openbaar Ministerie]]}}</ref>
On 23 June 2011, Wilders was acquitted of all charges, with Judge Marcel van Oosten noting that his statements, although "gross and denigrating," had not given rise to hatred against Muslims, and as such were "acceptable within the context of public debate."<ref name="acquitted2">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-13883331 |title=Geert Wilders cleared of hate charges by Dutch court |date=23 June 2011 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=23 June 2011}}</ref> Van Oosten also said, however, that Wilders's statements were on the edge of legal acceptability.<ref name="acquitted3">{{cite web |url=http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2011/06/wilders_found_not_guilty_of_in.php |title=Wilders found not guilty of inciting hatred, but is 'on the edge' |date=23 June 2011 |publisher=DutchNews.nl |accessdate=23 June 2011}}</ref>
==Background== According to Article 71 of the [[Constitution of the Netherlands|Dutch Constitution]], as an MP, Wilders has immunity with regard to anything he says in or writes to [[States-General of the Netherlands|parliament]].<ref>Constitution of the Kingdom of The Netherlands Article 71 (English translation; "[[States-General of the Netherlands|States General]]" = Dutch parliament): ''"Article 71 Members of the States General, Ministers, State Secretaries and other persons taking part in deliberations may not be prosecuted or otherwise held liable in law for anything they say during the sittings of the States General or of its committees or for anything they submit to them in writing."''</ref> However, this protection does not extend to opinions expressed outside of parliament, allowing for prosecution based on his criticism of Islam. The possibility that Wilders could be prosecuted became clear between 2007 and 2010, when protests against alleged insults and incitement to hatred resulted in his criminal prosecution by the [[district attorney]] in [[Amsterdam]]. On 3 February 2010, the Amsterdam court ruled itself to be competent on the charges against Wilders.
Some of his public comments, as well as some of the content of Wilders' film ''[[Fitna (film)|Fitna]]'', have been protested by agencies such as the Dutch anti-[[discrimination]] group ''Nederland Bekent Kleur'' ({{lang-nl|The Netherlands Shows True Colours}}).<ref name=declines/> On 15 August 2007, a representative of the public prosecution service in Amsterdam declared that dozens of reports filed against Wilders were being considered.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.elsevier.nl/web/10133280/Nieuws/Politiek/Aangiftes-tegen-Wilders-stromen-binnen.htm |title=Aangiftes tegen Wilders stromen binnen |publisher=[[Elsevier (magazine)|Elsevier]] |language=Dutch |date=15 November 2007 |accessdate=15 March 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081005032528/http://www.elsevier.nl/web/10133280/Nieuws/Politiek/Aangiftes-tegen-Wilders-stromen-binnen.htm |archivedate=5 October 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Attempts to prosecute Wilders under Dutch anti-[[hate speech]] laws in June 2008 were dropped, with the public prosecution stating that Wilders' comments contributed to the debate on Islam in Dutch society and had been made outside parliament. The office released a statement reading: "That comments are hurtful and offensive for a large number of Muslims does not mean that they are punishable. Freedom of expression fulfils an essential role in public debate in a democratic society. That means that offensive comments can be made in a political debate."<ref name=declines>{{cite news |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/06/30/europe/dutch.php |title=Holland declines to prosecute anti-Islam politician |date=30 June 2008 |accessdate=14 March 2009 |agency=[[Reuters]] |work=[[International Herald Tribune]]}}</ref><ref name=react/><ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/dutch-mp-to-be-tried-for-views-on-islam-1488654.html |title=Dutch MP to be tried for views on Islam |work=[[The Independent]] |date=22 January 2009 |accessdate=31 May 2011 |first=Vanessa |last=Mock}}</ref>
==Prosecution==
===Decision to try=== The plaintiffs (''Nederlands Bekent Kleur'', organisations of [[Turks in the Netherlands|Turkish]], [[Moroccan-Dutch|Moroccan]] and [[Antilles|Antillean]] people in the Netherlands, and an organization of [[mosque]]s) appealed against the prosecution's decision to not pursue the case and on 21 January 2009, a three-judge [[Appellate court|court of appeal]] ordered the public prosecutor to try Wilders.<ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article5563071.ece |work=[[The Times]] |accessdate=31 May 2011 |title=Anti-Islam MP Geert Wilders faces trial over controversial film |date=22 January 2009}}</ref> Their statement said that "[i]n a democratic system, hate speech is considered so serious that it is in the general interest to... draw a clear line" and that "the court also considers appropriate criminal prosecution for insulting Muslim worshippers because of comparisons between Islam and Nazism made by Wilders".<ref name=react/> If convicted, he could have been sentenced for up to 16 months of jail time or a fine of €9866.67.<ref name=forbes>{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/2009/01/25/geert-wilders-speech-oped-cx_dvh_0126vanhoogstraten.html |title=Holland Puts Offensiveness On Trial |last=van Hoogstraten |first=Diederik |date=26 January 2009 |accessdate=15 March 2009 |work=[[Forbes]]}}</ref> His lawyer [[Bram Moszkowicz]] tried to have the appeal overturned at the [[Hoge Raad der Nederlanden|Supreme Court of the Netherlands]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.radionetherlands.nl/currentaffairs/region/netherlands/090203-wilders-moszkowicz |title=Top lawyer to defend Dutch anti-Islam MP Wilders |last=Kievit |first=Rob |date=2 March 2009 |accessdate=15 March 2009 |publisher=[[Radio Netherlands Worldwide]]}}</ref> but the Supreme Court's Procurator General decided he would not hear the case.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nieuwsbank.nl/inp/2009/05/20/R137.htm |title=Verzoek Moszkowicz tot het instellen van een vordering tot cassatie |accessdate=27 May 2011 |last=Fokkens |first=J.W. |date=20 May 2009 |publisher=Procurator General of the Dutch Supreme Court / Nieuwsbank |language=Dutch}}</ref>
On 4 December 2009, Wilders was ordered to appear before the court on 20 January 2010 to defend himself against the charges of group insult of Muslims, fomenting hate and discrimination against Muslims because of their religion, and fomenting hate and discrimination against non-Western foreigners or Moroccans because of their race.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.elsevier.nl/web/Nieuws/Nederland/252551/Geert-Wilders-ontvangt-dagvaarding-voor-proces.htm |title=Geert Wilders ontvangt dagvaarding voor proces |work=[[Elsevier (magazine)|Elsevier]] |accessdate=31 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611231310/http://www.elsevier.nl/web/Nieuws/Nederland/252551/Geert-Wilders-ontvangt-dagvaarding-voor-proces.htm |archivedate=11 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> On 11 January 2010, the Dutch public prosecution service brought additional charges against him, charging him with hatred against Moroccans and non-Western immigrants.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rnw.nl/english/article/hate-speak-charges-against-geert-wilders-widened |title=Geert Wilders hate speech charges widened |publisher=[[Radio Netherlands Worldwide]] |accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2010/01/more_charges_against_wilders.php |title=More charges against Wilders |publisher=DutchNews.nl |date=13 January 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nrc.nl/international/article2462698.ece/Has_Wilders_broken_the_law |title=Has Wilders broken the law? |work=[[NRC Handelsblad]] |accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref>
On 13 January 2010, the Amsterdam court rejected, after a closed pretrial hearing, submissions by Wilders that one of the charges against him should be dropped or reduced. He argued that he had only criticized Islam and not its adherents, and that the charge of insulting Muslims as a group should not stand. His lawyer Moszkowicz petitioned judges to drop the charge of insulting Muslims as a group, which he said would have little chance of winning a conviction. He cited a 2009 Dutch Supreme Court ruling that found insulting a religion is not the same as insulting followers of that religion, and not punishable under the current [[hate speech]] laws. The judge said that the indictment only put into practice an earlier court ruling that he should stand trial and that the defense had not put forward any new evidence to overturn the ruling.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rnw.nl/english/article/judge-rejects-geert-wilders-submission |title=Judge rejects Geert Wilders' submission |publisher=[[Radio Netherlands Worldwide]] |date=14 January 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nrc.nl/international/article2459165.ece/Wilders_to_be_tried_for_hate_speech |title=Wilders to be tried for hate speech |publisher=[[NRC Handelsblad]] |date=14 January 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref>
====Charges==== In total, Wilders was charged with the following five counts: #Group [[insult]] #[[Hate crime|Inciting hatred]] against Muslims because of their religion #Inciting discrimination against Muslims because of their religion #Inciting hatred against non-western [[allochtoon|immigrants]] and Moroccans because of their race #Inciting discrimination against non-western immigrants and Moroccans because of their race
The first charge is based on article 137c of the Dutch criminal code, and the rest are based on article 137d, both concerning [[Hate speech#Netherlands|hate speech]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.om.nl/actueel-0/strafzaken/strafzaak_tegen/@154271/requisitoir-zaak/ |title=Requisitoir zaak-Wilders |publisher=[[Openbaar Ministerie]] |accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref>
===First trial=== Court proceedings began on 20 January 2010, with Wilders accused of discrimination on the basis of religion and spreading hate. On the eve of his trial, Wilders told journalists he expected to be acquitted, saying, "I have done nothing wrong." After receiving the [[summons]], he commented that he considered the prosecution as "a political trial."<ref>{{cite news |last=Murray |first=Douglas |url=http://blogs.telegraph.co.uk/news/douglasmurray/100024056/geert-wilders-on-trial-for-telling-the-truth/ |title=Geert Wilders: on trial for telling the truth |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=28 January 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref> He also announced his intention to call various experts to act as [[witness]]es.<ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article6994396.ece |work=[[The Times]] |accessdate=31 May 2011 |title=Far-right MP Geert Wilders on trial for discrimination against Muslims |first=David |last=Charter |date=20 January 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.expatica.com/nl/news/dutch-rss-news/wilders-trial-begins-in-amsterdam_20551.html |title=Wilders trial begins in Amsterdam |publisher=[[Expatica]] |accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www1.voanews.com/english/news/europe/Dutch-Politician-on-Trial-for-Anti-Muslim-Comments-82187757.html |title=Dutch Politician on Trial for Anti-Muslim Comments |publisher=[[Voice of America]] |date=20 January 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Waterfield |first=Bruno |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/netherlands/7037762/Geert-Wilders-in-Dutch-court-over-anti-Islam-comments.html |title=Geert Wilders in Dutch court over anti-Islam comments |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=20 January 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/europe/01/20/netherlands.geert.wilders/ |title=Filmmaker Geert Wilders faces hatred charges |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=20 January 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2010/01/201012094532873241.html |title=Dutch MP on trial for 'hate speech' |publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]] |accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref> On the first day of the trial, Wilders gave a speech invoking [[Thomas Jefferson]], among others.{{Citation needed|date=August 2013}}
When the trial resumed on 3 February, the judges decided who would be allowed to testify as witnesses. Wilders's desired witness list consisted of various experts on both the law and Islam, including university professors, radical imams, and [[Mohammed Bouyeri]], the man who murdered filmmaker [[Theo van Gogh (film director)|Theo van Gogh]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Goodenough |first=Patrick |url=http://www.cnsnews.com/news/article/60884 |title=Dutch Critic of Islam Wants Extremist Killer to Testify at His Trial |publisher=[[Cybercast News Service]] |date=3 February 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606071933/http://www.cnsnews.com/news/article/60884 |archivedate=6 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Other individuals on the list included [[Afshin Ellian]], a Dutch-Iranian professor at [[Leiden University]]; [[Hans Jansen]], a Dutch scholar of Islam; [[Wafa Sultan]], a [[Syrian American]] physician; [[Raphael Israeli]], a Moroccan-Israeli professor at the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]]; [[Andrew G. Bostom]], an American professor at [[Alpert Medical School]] of [[Brown University]]; [[Robert Spencer (author)|Robert Spencer]], an American author and blogger; and [[Ayatollah]]s [[Ahmad Jannati]] and [[Mohammad Yazdii]], members of the [[Iran]]ian [[Guardian Council]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.depers.nl/binnenland/401573/De-Getuigen.html |title=De getuigen |language=Dutch |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100125163948/http://www.depers.nl/binnenland/401573/De-Getuigen.html |archivedate=25 January 2010 }}</ref>
The court rejected 15 of Wilders's 18 desired witnesses, ruling that Bouyeri and other Muslim extremists would not be allowed to testify in the case. The court accepted only the three Islam experts whom Wilders had called, rejecting the lawyers and Islamic extremists.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nrc.nl/international/article2475574.ece/Van_Goghs_killer_rejected_as_Wilders_witness |title=Van Gogh's killer rejected as Wilders witness |work=[[NRC Handelsblad]] |date=4 February 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rnw.nl/english/article/court-rejects-wilders%E2%80%99-extremist-witnesses |title=Court rejects Wilders’ extremist witnesses |publisher=[[Radio Netherlands Worldwide]] |date=3 February 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2010/02/court_limits_wilders_witness_l.php |title=Court limits Wilders' witness list |publisher=DutchNews.nl |date=3 February 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref> The court also rejected the plea by Wilders's lawyer to transfer the case to the Supreme Court due to Wilders status as an MP. The court overruled this objection against its jurisdiction. "Parliamentary immunity does not extend to what a public representative says or writes outside of parliamentary gatherings." said Jan Moors, one of the judges at the Amsterdam court.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2010/01/wilders_trial_to_resume_in_feb.php |title=Wilders' trial to resume in February |publisher=DutchNews.nl |date=21 January 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rnw.nl/english/article/populist-mp-wilders-addresses-amsterdam-court |title=Populist MP Wilders addresses Amsterdam court |publisher=[[Radio Netherlands Worldwide]] |date=20 January 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nrc.nl/binnenland/proceswilders/article2474842.ece/Proces_tegen_Wilders_aangehouden |title=Proces tegen Wilders aangehouden |work=[[NRC Handelsblad]] |date=2 September 2008 |accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2010/02/201023181713918592.html |title=Dutch hate speech trial to proceed |publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=3 February 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKTRE6123B120100203 |title=Amsterdam court to hear case against far-right MP Wilders |publisher=[[Reuters]] |accessdate=31 May 2011 |date=3 February 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rnw.nl/english/article/geert-wilders-doesnt-get-his-way-court |title=Geert Wilders doesn't get his way in court |publisher=[[Radio Netherlands Worldwide]] |accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2010/02/wilders_witness_list_published.php |title=Wilders' witness list published today |publisher=DutchNews.nl |date=3 February 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref> Wilders consequently argued that he was being denied his [[right to a fair trial]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Goodenough |first=Patrick |url=http://www.cnsnews.com/news/article/60962 |title=Anti-Islam Dutch Lawmaker Says He’s Being Denied a Fair Trial; Court Rejects Most of His Witness List |publisher=[[Cybercast News Service]] |date=4 February 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606072003/http://www.cnsnews.com/news/article/60962 |archivedate=6 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
During the trial it became clear that the prosecutors were arguing for Wilders to be acquitted on all five counts.<ref name=OM1 />
On 22 October 2010, when the trial was nearing its conclusion, Wilders's attorney Moszkowicz asked for the judges to be [[substitution (law)|substituted]] because of a perceived bias against his client. Moszkowicz had unsuccessfully asked for substitution before. The second request was made because Tom Schalken, one of the judges in the court of appeal case that ordered the prosecution of Wilders on 21 January 2009 had allegedly tried to convince a witness in the main trial, Hans Jansen, that the trial was justified. Moszkowicz wanted to hear this witness immediately regarding the alleged conflict of interest, but the court decided it would not hear the witness. The substitution chamber decided that this decision had an appearance of bias and awarded the substitution, thereby ordering a [[New trial|retrial]].<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/oct/22/geert-wilders-trial-collapses Geert Wilders hate speech trial collapses in Netherlands], by Ian Traynor, Europe editor, guardian.co.uk, 22 October 2010</ref>
In the meantime, the alleged victims argued to the court of appeal that the prosecutors, by arguing for acquittal, had not fulfilled the court's order that Wilders had to be prosecuted, and that they should be replaced in the retrial. On 4 February 2011, the court of appeal decided against this complaint.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.om.nl/actueel-0/strafzaken/strafzaak_tegen/@154942/afwijzing_klacht/ |title=Afwijzing klacht inzake Wilders |accessdate=28 May 2011 |date=4 February 2011 |publisher=[[Openbaar Ministerie]] |language=Dutch}}</ref>
===Second trial=== On 7 February 2011, the retrial started. In the period between the trials, police investigated the claims that appellate judge Tom Schalken had tried to influence witness Hans Jansen. The new trial began with hearing the witnesses Schalken, Jansen, and Bertus Hendriks; the latter had hosted the dinner party at which Schalken spoke to Jansen. Moszkowicz argued that the trial against Geert Wilders could not continue because the witness had been influenced.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.depers.nl/binnenland/545242/Schalken-en-Jansen-gehoord.html |title=Schalken en Jansen gehoord als getuigen |accessdate=28 May 2011 |date=14 February 2011 |work=[[De Pers]] |language=Dutch |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110217153947/http://www.depers.nl/binnenland/545242/Schalken-en-Jansen-gehoord.html |archivedate=17 February 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> During the hearing of Hendriks, Moszkowicz claimed that Hendriks had committed [[perjury]]; when the judges did not agree, Moszkowicz tried unsuccessfully to have them substituted as well.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2011/04/wilders_inciting_hatred_trial_6.php |title=Wilders inciting hatred trial: no new judges says legal panel |accessdate=28 May 2011 |date=18 April 2011 |publisher=DutchNews.nl |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110419181744/http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2011/04/wilders_inciting_hatred_trial_6.php |archivedate=19 April 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
On 23 May 2011, the judges decided that although Schalken should not have talked to Jansen, the witness had not been influenced, and the case could continue.<ref>{{cite news |title=Dutch court rejects anti-Islam MP's bias claim |date=23 May 2011 |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gMCzMdfhehjAmFHA8rsnMO_780vw?docId=CNG.88fd56d674abda860b0428dc480c8b1d.3a1 |agency=[[Agence France-Presse|AFP]] |accessdate=28 May 2011}}</ref> As in the first trial, the public prosecution argued that Wilders should be acquitted on all counts. On 1 June the hearings concluded, with Geert Wilders asking the judges to [[Acquittal|find him not guilty]]. On 23 June 2011, Wilders was acquitted by the court of all charges, because his statements were, as presiding judge Marcel van Oosten put it, "acceptable within the context of public debate."<ref>{{cite news |title=Judgement of 23 June 2001 |author=[[Supreme Court of the Netherlands]] |url=http://zoeken.rechtspraak.nl/detailpage.aspx?ljn=BQ9001&u_ljn=BQ9001 |publisher=Supreme Court of the Netherlands |accessdate=12 July 2012 |language=Dutch}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Judgement of 23 June 2001 |author=[[Supreme Court of the Netherlands]] |url=http://www.rechtspraak.nl/SiteCollectionDocuments/Translation%20verdict%20Wilders%20230611.doc |publisher=Supreme Court of the Netherlands |accessdate=12 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120206100402/http://www.rechtspraak.nl/SiteCollectionDocuments/Translation%20verdict%20Wilders%20230611.doc |archivedate=6 February 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Because both the public prosecutor and the defense requested complete acquittal, the verdict will most likely not be appealed,<ref name=acquitted1 /><ref name=acquitted3 /> although some thought the plaintiffs might try to take the case before the [[European Court of Human Rights]].<ref name=acquitted2 />

The American [[Middle East Forum]] set up a [[legal defense fund]] for Wilders.<ref>{{cite web|authors=Anthony Deutsch & Mark Hosenball|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-dutch-wilders-us-idUSBRE8890A720120910|title=Exclusive: U.S. groups helped fund Dutch anti-Islam politician Wilders|agency=Reuters|date=10 September 2012}}</ref>
The Dutch writer and historian [[Ian Buruma]], writing in an [[op-ed]] published in the ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]'', argued that "for a man who calls for a ban on the Koran to act as the champion of free speech is a bit rich."<ref name=ian>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/30/opinion/30buruma.html |title=Totally Tolerant, Up to a Point |last=Buruma |first=Ian | authorlink = Ian Buruma |date=29 January 2009 |accessdate=15 March 2009 |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref>
A February 2009 survey by [[Angus Reid Global Monitor]] found that Dutch [[public opinion]] was deeply split on the prosecution, with 50% supporting Wilders and 43% opposed.<ref name=react>{{cite news |url=http://www.angus-reid.com/polls/view/32758/dutch_react_to_prosecution_of_wilders |title=Dutch React to Prosecution of Wilders |date=3 February 2009 |accessdate=15 March 2009 |publisher=[[Angus Reid Global Monitor]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090205220806/http://www.angus-reid.com/polls/view/32758/dutch_react_to_prosecution_of_wilders |archivedate=5 February 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> However, public support for the [[Party for Freedom]] vastly increased since Wilders's legal troubles began, virtually tying with the People's Party for Freedom and Democracy as the third most popular national party.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dag.nl/binnenland/tumult-pvv-218531 |title=Uproar for PVV |date=25 January 2009 |accessdate=15 March 2009 |language=Dutch |publisher=[[DAG (newspaper)|DAG]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100102075502/http://www.dag.nl/binnenland/tumult-pvv-218531 |archivedate=2 January 2010 }}</ref> According to [[Radio Netherlands Worldwide|Radio Netherlands]], "Dutch politicians themselves seem to be keeping quiet on the issue; they are probably worried that media attention will only serve to make the controversial politician more popular."<ref name=nicola>{{cite news |url=http://www.radionetherlands.nl/currentaffairs/region/netherlands/090122-wilders-reactions |title=Worldwide reactions to Wilders' prosecution |last=Chadwick |first=Nicola |date=22 January 2009 |accessdate=15 March 2009 |publisher=[[Radio Netherlands Worldwide]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090331222921/http://www.radionetherlands.nl/currentaffairs/region/netherlands/090122-wilders-reactions |archivedate=31 March 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
[[Robert Spencer (writer)|Robert Spencer]], creator of [[Jihad Watch]] and author of articles and books relating to Islam and [[Islamic terrorism]], wrote on [[National Review|National Review Online]] that "The Geert Wilders trial ought to be an international media event; seldom has any court case anywhere had such enormous implications for the future of the free world."<ref>{{cite web |author=NRO Symposium |url=http://article.nationalreview.com/424251/western-civilization-on-trial/nro-symposium |title=Western Civilization on Trial – Why we should be watching Geert Wilders |publisher=[[National Review]] |date=8 February 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100211125355/http://article.nationalreview.com/424251/western-civilization-on-trial/nro-symposium |archivedate=11 February 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Free speech=== Wilders believed that his freedom of speech and traditional European freedoms were the primary subject of the trial. In February 2010, in an interview with [[Israel National Radio]], Wilders said he was "fighting for one thing: the preservation of our culture, which is based on Christianity, Judaism and humanism – and not on Islam... While Islamization of our society grows, the political elite looks in the other direction and ignores the real problem, namely, the impending loss of our freedom. I am fighting not against Moslems, but against the influx of a totalitarian ideology called Islam."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/135935 |title="Geert Wilders to INN: "Traditional European Freedom at Stake" |publisher=[[Arutz Sheva]] |accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/Radio/News.aspx/1923 |title=Audio: Geert Wilders and Feiglin |publisher=[[Arutz Sheva]] |date=8 February 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref> He has cited [[Gregorius Nekschot]], a similar case of Islam related free-speech restrictions, on his website.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://pvv.nl/index.php/component/content/article/36-geert-wilders/4316-creeping-sharia.html |title=Creeping sharia |publisher=[[Party for Freedom]] |accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref>
After being cleared of all charges, Wilders commented that the victory was not only an acquittal for himself, but a victory for [[Human rights in the Netherlands|freedom of expression in the Netherlands]].<ref name=acquitted2 /> Commentators believed that the plaintiffs may attempt to bring their case before the [[European Court of Human Rights]].<ref name=acquitted2 /> Gerard Spong, a lawyer instrumental in getting the case heard, expressed his disappointment with the verdict, seeing the judge's ruling based on "public context" as vague. Theo de Roos, professor of law at the [[Tilburg University]], saw the case as a precedent for [[Incitement to ethnic or racial hatred|ethnic incitement]] in Dutch law, prohibiting only actual threats.<ref name=acquitted3 />

{{multiple issues| {{Editorial|date=April 2011}} {{Refimprove|date=April 2011}} }}
[[File:Tsunami evac sign Seaside Oregon.JPG|thumb|300px|Evacuation route sign in a low-lying coastal area on the West Coast of the United States]] A '''tsunami warning system''' ('''TWS''') is used to detect [[tsunami]]s in advance and issue warnings to prevent loss of life and damage to property. It is made up of two equally important components: a network of sensors to detect tsunamis and a communications infrastructure to issue timely alarms to permit evacuation of the coastal areas. There are two distinct types of tsunami warning systems: '''international''' and '''regional'''. When operating, seismic alerts are used to instigate the watches and warnings; then, data from observed sea level height (either shore-based tide gauges or [[Deep-ocean Assessment and Reporting of Tsunamis|DART]] buoys) are used to verify the existence of a tsunami. Other systems have been proposed to augment the warning procedures; for example, it has been suggested that the duration and frequency content of [[T wave (seismic)|t-wave]] energy (which is earthquake energy trapped in the ocean [[SOFAR channel]]) is indicative of an earthquake's tsunami potential.<ref>Salzberg, 2006</ref>
==History and forecasting== {{unreferenced|section|date=June 2017}} The first rudimentary system to alert communities of an impending tsunami was attempted in [[Hawaii]] in the 1920s. More advanced systems were developed in the wake of the April 1, 1946 (caused by the [[1946 Aleutian Islands earthquake]]) and May 23, 1960 (caused by the [[1960 Valdivia earthquake]]) tsunamis which caused massive devastation in [[Hilo, Hawaii]]. While tsunamis travel at between 500 and 1,000 km/h (around 0.14 and 0.28 km/s) in open water, earthquakes can be detected almost at once as [[seismic wave]]s travel with a typical speed of 4 km/s (around 14,400 km/h). This gives time for a possible tsunami forecast to be made and warnings to be issued to threatened areas, if warranted. Until a reliable model is able to predict which earthquakes will produce significant tsunamis, this approach will produce many more false alarms than verified warnings.
==International systems (IS)==
===Pacific Ocean=== [[File:TsunamiHazardSign.svg|right|thumb|Japanese Tsunami warning sign]] Tsunami warnings for most of the [[Pacific Ocean]] are issued by the [[Pacific Tsunami Warning Center]] (PTWC), operated by the [[United States]] [[NOAA]] in [[Ewa Beach, Hawaii]]. NOAA's [[National Tsunami Warning Center]] (NTWC) in [[Palmer, Alaska]] issues warnings for the west coast of North America, including Alaska, British Columbia, Oregon and California. The PTWC was established in 1949, following the 1946 [[Aleutian Island earthquake]] and a tsunami that resulted in 165 casualties on Hawaii and in Alaska; NTWC was founded in 1967. International coordination is achieved through the International Coordination Group for the Tsunami Warning System in the Pacific, established by the [[Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission]] of [[UNESCO]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ioc.unesco.org/itsu/ |title=IOC Oceans | United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization |publisher=Ioc.unesco.org |date= |accessdate=2018-10-02}}</ref>
In 2017, The US congressional panel passed a vote to continue funding a global tsunami detection system that gives U.S. officials an accurate forecast in order to decrease damage cause by Tsunamis.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.virginislandsdailynews.com/ap/threatened-by-trump-s-budget-tsunami-warning-system-gets-backing/article_7ab750c2-46dd-57b5-8d51-711f2435e6b5.html|title=Threatened by Trump's budget, tsunami warning system gets backing from congressional panel|last=Times|first=Los Angeles|work=The Virgin Islands Daily News|access-date=2017-07-18|language=en}}</ref>
===Indian Ocean (ICG/IOTWS)=== {{main article|Indian Ocean Tsunami Warning System}}
[[File:Tsunami-warning-centre hikkaduwa sri-lanka.jpg|right|thumb|Tsunami Early Warning Tower board in Hikkaduwa, Sri Lanka]]
After the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake|2004 Indian Ocean Tsunami]] which killed almost 250,000 people, a [[United Nations]] conference was held in January 2005 in [[Kobe]], [[Japan]], and decided that as an initial step towards an [[International Early Warning Programme]], the UN should establish an [[Indian Ocean Tsunami Warning System]]. This then resulted in a system of warnings in Indonesia and other affected areas.
===North Eastern Atlantic, the Mediterranean and Connected Seas (ICG/NEAMTWS)=== The First United Session of the Inter-governmental Coordination Group for the Tsunami Early Warning and Mitigation System in the North Eastern Atlantic, the Mediterranean and connected Seas (ICG/NEAMTWS), established by the [[Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission]] of [[UNESCO]] Assembly during its 23rd Session in June 2005, through Resolution XXIII.14, took place in [[Rome]] on 21 and 22 November 2005.
The meeting, hosted by the Government of Italy (the [[Italian Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] and the [[Ministry of the Environment (Italy)|Italian Ministry for the Environment and Protection of Land and Sea]]), was attended by more than 150 participants from 24 countries, 13 organizations and numerous observers.
===Caribbean===
A Caribbean-wide tsunami warning system was planned to be instituted by the year 2010, by representatives of [[Caribbean Community|Caribbean nations]] who met in [[Panama City]] in March 2008. [[Panama]]'s last major tsunami killed 4,500 people in 1882.<ref>[http://uk.reuters.com/article/environmentNews/idUKN1332624020080313 Reuters:Caribbean plans tsunami warning system by 2010]</ref> [[Barbados]] has said it will review or test its tsunami protocol in February 2010 as a regional pilot.<ref>{{cite news |title=Time right to test disaster awareness system |author= |first=Carol |last=Martindale |url=http://www.nationnews.com/news/local/tsunami-protocol-in-full-effect-copy-for-web |newspaper=[[The Daily Nation (Barbados)|Nation Newspaper]] |date=24 January 2010 |page= |pages= |at= |accessdate=24 January 2010 |quote=A TSUNAMI PROTOCOL to be tested here next month will help Barbadians be better prepared to deal with natural disasters such as earthquakes. ... Harewood said Barbados was nominated and accepted as the "pilot state" for the tsunami protocol which will be discussed from February 22 to 26. He said the objective of the Standard Operational Procedure and Communications Protocol, which has been being worked on for the last two years, is to provide more information on what must be done in the event of a tsunami, earthquake or any other major disaster. He noted that one of the things they would be doing was adopting a general public service announcement through the Government Information Service (GIS) to help increase awareness of tsunamis. }}</ref>{{update after|2014|7}}
==Regional warning systems== Regional (or local) warning system centres use [[seismic]] data about nearby recent earthquakes to determine if there is a possible local threat of a tsunami. Such systems are capable of issuing warnings to the general public (via public address systems and sirens) in less than 15 minutes. Although the [[epicenter]] and [[moment magnitude scale|moment magnitude]] of an underwater quake and the probable tsunami arrival times can be quickly calculated, it is almost always impossible to know whether underwater ground shifts have occurred which will result in tsunami waves. As a result, false alarms can occur with these systems, but the disruption is small, which makes sense due to the highly localised nature of these extremely quick warnings, in combination with how difficult it would be for a false alarm to affect more than a small area of the system. Real tsunamis would affect more than just a small portion.{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}}
===Japan=== Japan has a nationwide tsunami warning system. The system usually issues the warning minutes after an [[Earthquake Early Warning (Japan)|Earthquake Early Warning]] (EEW) is issued, should there be expected waves.<ref>{{cite web|title=Japan Meteorological Agency｜Flow of issuance of information about tsunami and earthquake|url=http://www.data.jma.go.jp/svd/eqev/data/en/guide/info.html|accessdate=15 April 2016}}</ref><ref name="2011warning">{{cite web|title=80 Seconds of Warning for Tokyo|url=https://www.technologyreview.com/s/423274/80-seconds-of-warning-for-tokyo/|website=MIT Technology Review|accessdate=15 April 2016}}</ref> The tsunami warning was issued within 3 minutes with the most serious rating on its warning scale during the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]]; it was rated as a "major tsunami", being at least 3 m (9.8 ft) high.<ref name="2011warning"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Emergency Warning System Starting Shortly|url=http://www.jma.go.jp/jma/en/Emergency_Warning/Leaflet(Emergency_Warning).pdf|accessdate=15 April 2016}}</ref> An improved system was unveiled on March 7, 2013 following the 2011 disaster to better access the waves.<ref>{{cite web|title=Leaflet "Start of New Tsunami Warning System Operation"|url=http://www.data.jma.go.jp/svd/eqev/data/en/tsunami/tsunamiwarning-leaflet.pdf|accessdate=15 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Tsunami two years on: Japan finally gets warning system that would have saved hundreds of lives|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/japan/9920042/Tsunami-two-years-on-Japan-finally-gets-warning-system-that-would-have-saved-hundreds-of-lives.html|accessdate=15 April 2016}}</ref>
==Conveying the warning== {{unreferenced|section|date=June 2017}} [[File:Okumatsushima tsunami P1130317 rotated.jpg|thumb|Mast with warning system, and sign detailing escape routes, on the coast of [[Okumatsushima]], [[Miyagi Prefecture|Miyagi]] prefecture, [[Japan]] (this coast was severely hit by the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|2011 tsunami]])]] Detection and prediction of tsunamis is only half the work of the system. Of equal importance is the ability to warn the populations of the areas that will be affected. All tsunami warning systems feature multiple lines of communications (such as [[SMS]], [[e-mail]], [[fax]], [[radio]], texting and [[teleprinter|telex]], often using hardened dedicated systems) enabling emergency messages to be sent to the [[emergency service]]s and [[armed forces]], as well to population-alerting systems (e.g. [[siren (noisemaker)|sirens]]) and systems like the [[Emergency Alert System]].
==Shortcomings== {{unreferenced|section|date=June 2017}} With the speed at which tsunami waves travel through open water, no system can protect against a very sudden tsunami, where the coast in question is too close to the [[epicenter]]. A devastating tsunami occurred off the coast of [[Hokkaidō]] in Japan as a result of [[1993 Hokkaidō earthquake|an earthquake on July 12, 1993]]. As a result, 202 people on the small island of [[Okushiri, Hokkaido]] lost their lives, and hundreds more were missing or injured. This tsunami struck just three to five minutes after the quake, and most victims were caught while fleeing for higher ground and secure places after surviving the earthquake. This was also the case in [[Aceh]], Indonesia.
While there remains the potential for sudden devastation from a tsunami, warning systems can be effective. For example, if there were a very large [[subduction zone]] [[earthquake]] ([[moment magnitude scale|moment magnitude]] 9.0) off the west coast of the [[United States]], people in [[Japan]], would therefore have more than 12 hours (and likely warnings from warning systems in Hawaii and elsewhere) before any tsunami arrived, giving them some time to evacuate areas likely to be affected.

{{short description|The practice of cultivating, processing and distributing food in or around urban areas}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} [[File:New crops-Chicago urban farm.jpg|thumb|250px|An urban farm in [[Chicago]]]] {{farming}} '''Urban agriculture,''' '''urban farming''', or '''urban gardening''' is the practice of cultivating, processing and distributing [[food]] in or around [[urban areas]].Bailkey, M., and J. Nasr. 2000. "From Brownfields to Greenfields: Producing Food in North American Cities," ''Community Food Security News''. Fall 1999/Winter 2000:6 Urban agriculture can also involve [[animal husbandry]], [[aquaculture]], [[agroforestry]], [[urban beekeeping]], and [[horticulture]]. These activities occur in [[peri-urban]] areas as well, and [[peri-urban agriculture]] may have different characteristics.{{cite web|url=https://www.fanrpan.org/archive/documents/d00780/|title=The role of urban agriculture in addressing household poverty and food security: the case of Zambia|author1=Hampwaye, G.|author2=Nel, E.|date=|website=|publisher=Gdnet.org|accessdate=1 April 2013|author3=Ingombe, L.|lastauthoramp=yes}} Urban agriculture can reflect varying levels of economic and social development. It may be a social movement for sustainable communities, where organic growers, "foodies," and "[[locavore]]s" form social networks founded on a shared ethos of nature and community holism. These networks can evolve when receiving formal institutional support, becoming integrated into local town planning as a "transition town" movement for sustainable urban development. For others, [[food security]], nutrition, and income generation are key motivations for the practice. In either case, more direct access to fresh vegetables, fruits, and meat products through urban agriculture can improve food security and [[food safety]]. ==History== In semi-desert towns of Persia, oases were fed through aqueducts that carried mountain water to support intensive food production, nurtured by wastes from the communities.{{Cite book|title=Continuous productive urban landscapes : designing urban agriculture for sustainable cities|last=André.|first=Viljoen|date=2005|publisher=Architectural Press|others=Bohn, Katrin., Howe, J. (Joe)|isbn=9780750655439|location=Oxford|oclc=60533269}} In [[Machu Picchu]], water was conserved and reused as part of the stepped architecture of the city, and vegetable beds were designed to gather sun in order to prolong the growing season. [[File:City experiment in gardening, New York City LCCN93501876.jpg|thumb|left|A gardening demonstration in New York City, 1922]] The idea of supplemental food production beyond rural farming operations and distant imports is not new. It has been used during war and depression times when food shortage issues arose, as well as during times of relative abundance. [[Allotment garden]]s came up in Germany in the early 19th century as a response to poverty and food insecurity.{{Cite web |url=http://www2.gtz.de/Dokumente/oe44/ecosan/nl/en-allotment-gardens-cagayan-de-oro-2005.pdf |title=untitles |access-date=13 March 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719034258/http://www2.gtz.de/Dokumente/oe44/ecosan/nl/en-allotment-gardens-cagayan-de-oro-2005.pdf |archive-date=19 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} In 1893, citizens of a depression-struck [[Detroit]] were asked to use any vacant lots to grow vegetables. They were nicknamed Pingree's Potato Patches after the mayor, [[Hazen S. Pingree]], who came up with the idea. He intended for these gardens to produce income, food supply, and even boost independence during times of hardship.{{cite web|title=Hazen S. Pingree Monument|url=http://historicdetroit.org/building/hazen-s-pingree-monument/|website=http://historicdetroit.org/|publisher=DAN AUSTIN}} [[Victory garden]]s sprouted during WWI and WWII and were fruit, vegetable, and herb gardens in US, Canada, and UK. This effort was undertaken by citizens to reduce pressure on food production that was to support the war effort. During the first World War, President Woodrow Wilson called upon all American citizens to utilize any available open space for food growth, seeing this as a way to pull them out of a potentially damaging situation. Because most of Europe was consumed with war, they were unable to produce sufficient food supplies to be shipped to the U.S., and a new plan was implemented with the intent to feed the U.S. and even supply a surplus to other countries in need. By the year 1919, over 5 million plots were growing food and over 500 million pounds of produce was harvested. [[File:MONTREUIL - Le clos des peches.jpg|thumb|Peaches in [[Montreuil, Seine-Saint-Denis]], [[France]]]] A very similar practice came into use during the Great Depression that provided a purpose, a job, and food to those who would otherwise be without anything during such harsh times. In this case, these efforts helped to raise spirits socially as well as to boost economic growth. Over 2.8 million dollars worth of food was produced from the subsistence gardens during the Depression. By the time of the Second World War, the War/Food Administration set up a National Victory Garden Program that set out to systematically establish functioning agriculture within cities. With this new plan in action, as many as 5.5 million Americans took part in the victory garden movement and over 9 million pounds of fruit and vegetables were grown a year, accounting for 44% of U.S.-grown produce throughout that time.{{citation needed|date=April 2013}} [[Community garden]]ing in most communities are open to the public and provide space for citizens to cultivate plants for food or recreation. A community gardening program that is well-established is Seattle's [[P-Patch]]. The grassroots [[permaculture]] movement has been hugely influential in the renaissance of urban agriculture throughout the world. The Severn Project in Bristol was started in 2010 for £2500 and provides 34 tons of produce per year, employing people from disadvantaged backgrounds.{{cite web|title=The Severn Project|url=http://www.thesevernproject.org/our-story/}} ==City farming== {{refimprove section|date=November 2018}} [[File:Mudchute farm cow head.jpg|rt|thumb|250px|A cow at Mudchute Park and Farm, Tower Hamlets, London. Note [[Canary Wharf]] in the background.]] {{anchor|City farm}}''City farms'' are agricultural plots in [[urban area]]s, which involve people working with [[Animal agriculture|animals]] and plants to produce food. City farms are usually [[Community gardening|community-run gardens]] which aim to improve community relationships and offer an awareness of [[agriculture]] and [[farming]] to people who live in urbanized areas. City farms are important sources of [[food security]] for many communities around the globe. City farms vary in size from small plots in private yards to larger farms that occupy a number of acres. In 1996, a United Nations report estimated there are over 800 million people worldwide who grow food and raise livestock in cities.{{Cite journal | last=Lawson| first=Laura| date=2016-12-22| title=Agriculture: Sowing the city| url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v540/n7634/full/540522a.html| journal=Nature| language=en| volume=540| issue=7634| pages=522–524| doi=10.1038/540522a| issn=0028-0836| bibcode=2016Natur.540..522L}} Although some city farms have paid employees, most rely heavily on volunteer labour, and some are run by volunteers alone. Other city farms operate as partnerships with [[local authority|local authorities]]. During the 1960s a number of [[community gardens]] were established in the [[United Kingdom]], influenced by the community garden movement in the [[United States]]. The first city farm was set up in 1972 in [[Kentish Town]], [[London]]. It combined farm animals with gardening space, an addition inspired by children's farms in the [[Netherlands]]. Other city farms followed across London and the United Kingdom. In Australia, several city farms exist in various capital cities. In [[Melbourne]], the [[Collingwood Children's Farm]] was established in 1979 on the Abbotsford Precinct Heritage Farmlands (the APHF), the oldest continually farmed land in [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], farmed since 1838. In 2010, New York City saw the building and opening of the world's largest privately owned and operated [[rooftop farm]], followed by an even larger location in 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/new-york-could-grown-all-its-own-food-180949748/|title=History, Travel, Arts, Science, People, Places - Smithsonian|work=smithsonianmag.com}} Both were a result of municipal programs such as The Green Roof Tax Abatement Program{{cite web|url=http://www.nyc.gov/html/dob/html/sustainability/green_roofs.shtml|title=Department of Buildings|work=nyc.gov|access-date=9 February 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160213083527/http://www.nyc.gov/html/dob/html/sustainability/green_roofs.shtml|archive-date=13 February 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} and Green Infrastructure Grant Program.https://a826-web01.nyc.gov/GIGrant/ [[File:Aretxabaleta-apts-and-garden-4618.jpg|thumb|rt|250px|A tidy front yard flower and vegetable garden in [[Aretxabaleta]], [[Spain]]]] ==Perspectives== ===Resource and economic=== The Urban Agriculture Network has defined urban agriculture as:{{Cite book|title=Urban agriculture : food, jobs and sustainable cities|date=1996|publisher=United Nations Development Programme|others=Cheema, G. Shabbir., Smit, Jac., Ratta, Annu., Nasr, Joe., United Nations Development Programme., Urban Agriculture Network.|isbn=9789211260472|location=New York, N.Y.|oclc=34575217}}
[A]n industry that produces, processes, and markets food, fuel, and other outputs, largely in response to the daily demand of consumers within a town, city, or [[metropolis]], on many types of privately and publicly held land and water bodies found throughout intra-urban and peri-urban areas. Typically urban agriculture applies [[intensive agriculture|intensive production]] methods, frequently using and reusing natural resources and urban wastes, to yield a diverse array of land-, water-, and air-based fauna and flora contributing to the food security, health, livelihood, and environment of the individual, household, and community.
Globalization has removed the need and ability of a community's agency in their food production. This results in an inability to address food injustice on a smaller, more manageable scale. This is especially true in cities. Today, most cities have lots of vacant land due to urban sprawl and home foreclosures. This land could be used to address food insecurity. One study of Cleveland shows that city could actually meet up to 100% of its fresh produce need. This would prevent up to $115 million in annual economic leakage. Using the rooftop space of New York City would also be able to provide roughly twice the amount of space necessary to supply New York City with its green vegetable yields. Space could be even better optimized through the usage of hydroponic or indoor factory production of food. Growing gardens within cities would also cut down on the amount of food waste. In order to fund these projects, it would require financial capital in the form of private enterprises or government funding. {{Cite journal|last=Grewal|first=Sharanbir S.|last2=Grewal|first2=Parwinder S.|title=Can cities become self-reliant in food?|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0264275111000692|journal=Cities|volume=29|issue=1|pages=1–11|doi=10.1016/j.cities.2011.06.003|year=2012}} ===Environmental=== The [[Council for Agricultural Science and Technology]] (CAST) defines urban agriculture to include aspects of environmental health, remediation, and recreation:{{cite web|url=http://www.cast-science.org |author=Butler, L. and D.M. Moronek (eds.)|date=May 2002 |title=Urban and Agriculture Communities: Opportunities for Common Ground |publisher=Council for Agricultural Science and Technology |location=Ames, Iowa |accessdate=1 April 2013}}
Urban agriculture is a complex system encompassing a spectrum of interests, from a traditional core of activities associated with the production, processing, marketing, distribution, and consumption, to a multiplicity of other benefits and services that are less widely acknowledged and documented. These include recreation and leisure; economic vitality and business entrepreneurship, individual health and well-being; community health and well being; landscape beautification; and environmental restoration and remediation.
Modern planning and design initiatives{{cite journal|url=http://geoffboeing.com/publications/how-neighborhoods-lost-food/|author=Boeing, G.|title=How Our Neighborhoods Lost Food, and How They Can Get It Back|journal=Progressive Planning|date=2016|volume=206|issue=Winter|pages=35–37|accessdate=2016-10-12}} are often more responsive to this model of urban agriculture because it fits within the current scope of [[sustainable design]]. The definition allows for a multitude of interpretations across cultures and time. Frequently it is tied to policy decisions to build sustainable cities.{{cite journal | last1 = Fraser | first1 = Evan D.G. | year = 2002 | title = Urban Ecology in Bangkok Thailand: Community Participation, Urban Agriculture and Forestry | url = | journal = Environments | volume = 30 | issue = | page = 1 }} Urban farms also provide unique opportunities for individuals, especially those living in cities, to get actively involved with ecological citizenship. By reconnecting with food production and nature, urban community gardening teaches individuals the skills necessary to participate in a democratic society. Decisions must be made on a group-level basis in order to run the farm. Most effective results are achieved when residents of a community are asked to take on more active roles in the farm. Katharine Travaline & Christian Hunold (2010) Urban agriculture and ecological citizenship in Philadelphia, Local Environment, 15:6, 581-590, DOI: 10.1080/13549839.2010.487529 ===Food security=== {{main article |Food security}} Access to nutritious food, both economically and geographically, is another perspective in the effort to locate food and livestock production in cities. With the tremendous influx of world population to urban areas, the need for fresh and safe food is increased. The [[Community Food Security Coalition]] (CFSC) defines food security as:
All persons in a community having access to culturally acceptable, nutritionally adequate food through local, non-emergency sources at all times.
Areas faced with food security issues have limited choices, often relying on highly [[food processing|processed]] [[fast food]] or convenience store foods that are high in calories and low in nutrients, which may lead to elevated rates of diet-related illnesses such as diabetes. These problems have brought about the concept of [[food justice]] which Alkon and Norgaard (2009; 289) explain is, "places access to healthy, affordable, culturally appropriate food in the contexts of institutional racism, racial formation, and racialized geographies.... Food justice serves as a theoretical and political bridge between scholarship and activism on sustainable agriculture, food insecurity, and [[environmental justice]]." {{cite journal | doi=10.1111/j.1475-682x.2009.00291.x |title=Breaking the Food Chains: An Investigation of Food Justice Activism |journal=Sociological Inquiry |volume=79 |issue=3 |pages=289–305 |year=2009 |last1=Alkon |first1=Alison Hope |last2=Norgaard |first2=Kari Marie}} Some systematic reviews have already explored urban agriculture contribution to food security and other determinants of health outcomes (see {{cite journal |doi=10.2196/resprot.9427 |pmid=29588270 |pmc=5893886 |title=Impacts of Urban Agriculture on the Determinants of Health: Scoping Review Protocol |journal=JMIR |volume=7 |issue=3 |pages=e89 |year=2018 |last1=Audate |first1=PP |last2=Fernandez |first2=MA |last3=Cloutier |first3=G |last4=Lebel |first4=A }} http://www.researchprotocols.org/2018/3/e89) ==Impact== [[File: Sprouting mung beans in a jar.jpg|thumb|A [[sprouting]] glass jar with mung beans in it]] ===Economic=== Urban and peri-urban agriculture (UPA) expands the economic base of the city through production, processing, packaging, and [[agricultural marketing|marketing]] of consumable products. This results in an increase in entrepreneurial activities and the [[job creation|creation of jobs]], as well as reducing food costs and improving quality.Urban agriculture for sustainable cities: using wastes and idle land and water bodies as resources. Jac Smit, Joe Nasr. ''Environment and Urbanization,'' Vol 4, Issue 2, pp. 141 - 152. First Published October 1, 1992. https://doi.org/10.1177/095624789200400214 UPA provides employment, income, and access to food for urban populations, which helps to relieve chronic and emergency food insecurity. Chronic food insecurity refers to less affordable food and growing [[urban poverty]], while emergency food insecurity relates to breakdowns in the chain of [[food distribution]]. UPA plays an important role in making food more affordable and in providing emergency supplies of food.{{cite web |url=http://www.fao.org/fcit/upa/en/ |author=Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations |title=Urban and Peri-urban Agriculture, Household Food Security and Nutrition |publisher=FAO |accessdate=1 April 2013}} Research into market values for produce grown in urban gardens has attributed to a [[community garden]] plot a median yield value of between approximately $200 and $500 (US, adjusted for inflation).[http://www.sarep.ucdavis.edu/newsltr/v7n3/sa-10.htm Sommers, L., and B. Butterfield, as cited in: Blair, D., C. Giesecke, and S. Sherman. (1991). "A Dietary, Social and Economic Evaluation of the Philadelphia Urban Gardening Project," ''Journal of Nutrition Education''.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070716000637/http://www.sarep.ucdavis.edu/newsltr/v7n3/sa-10.htm |date=16 July 2007 }} ===Social=== [[File:Kstovo-hay-1536.jpg|thumb|The needs of urban landscaping can be combined with those of suburban livestock farmers. ([[Kstovo]], Russia).]] Urban agriculture can have a large impact on the social and emotional well-being of individuals. {{cite journal |doi=10.1093/heapro/dam001 |pmid=17324956 |title=Growing urban health: Community gardening in South-East Toronto |journal=Health Promotion International |volume=22 |issue=2 |pages=92–101 |year=2007 |last1=Wakefield |first1=S. |last2=Yeudall |first2=F. |last3=Taron |first3=C. |last4=Reynolds |first4=J. |last5=Skinner |first5=A. }} UA can have an overall positive impact on [[community health]], which directly impacts individuals social and emotional well-being. Urban gardens are often places that facilitate positive [[social interaction]], which also contributes to overall social and emotional well-being. Many gardens facilitate the improvement of social networks within the communities that they are located. For many neighborhoods, gardens provide a “symbolic focus,” which leads to increased neighborhood pride.{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S1353-8292(00)00013-7 |pmid=11027957 |title=A survey of community gardens in upstate New York: Implications for health promotion and community development |journal=Health & Place |volume=6 |issue=4 |pages=319–27 |year=2000 |last1=Armstrong |first1=Donna }} Related to the previous point, urban agriculture increases community participation through sensibilization and diagnostic workshops or different commissions in the area of vegetable gardens. Activities which involve hundreds of people.{{Cite web|url=http://sior.ub.edu/jspui/cris/socialimpact/socialimpact00444|title=Increased community participation. [Social Impact]. Cities Without Hunger - Community Gardens: Sao Paulo (2003-2009).|last=|first=|date=|website=SIOR, Social Impact Open Repository|access-date=}} When individuals come together around UA, physical activity levels are often increased. Many state that working in agriculture is much more interesting and fulfilling than going to the gym, and that it makes getting [[physical exercise|exercise]] “fun.” In addition to the exercise that individuals receive while actually working in gardens, many people say that the majority of the exercise they receive through urban agriculture is actually getting to the gardens—many people either walk or ride their bike to the sites, which provides many physical benefits.{{cite journal |doi=10.1080/02614360902769894 |title=Cultivating health and wellbeing: Members' perceptions of the health benefits of a Port Melbourne community garden |journal=Leisure Studies |volume=28 |issue=2 |pages=207–19 |year=2009 |last1=Kingsley |first1=Jonathan 'Yotti' |last2=Townsend |first2=Mardie |last3=Henderson‐Wilson |first3=Claire }} UPA can be seen as a means of improving the [[livelihood]] of people living in and around cities. Taking part in such practices is seen mostly as informal activity, but in many cities where inadequate, unreliable, and irregular access to food is a recurring problem, urban agriculture has been a positive response to tackling food concerns. Due to the food security that comes with UA, feelings of independence and empowerment often arise. The ability to produce and grow food for oneself has also been reported to improve levels of self-esteem or of self-efficacy. Households and small communities take advantage of vacant land and contribute not only to their household food needs but also the needs of their resident city.[http://www.mygreenhobby.com/urban-agriculture-why-it-has-a-positive-impact/ Hales et al. (2016). "Urban Agriculture: Urban agriculture, positive impact"] ''My Green Hobby'' The CFSC states that:
Community and residential gardening, as well as small-scale farming, save household food dollars. They promote nutrition and free cash for non-garden foods and other items. As an example, you can raise your own chickens on an urban farm and have fresh eggs for only $0.44 per dozen.What's the Real Cost of Raising Backyard Chickens? (2015, March 29). Retrieved April 2, 2015, from http://www.urbanfarminghq.com/cost-of-raising-backyard-chickens/ {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402184950/http://www.urbanfarminghq.com/cost-of-raising-backyard-chickens/ |date=2 April 2015 }}
This allows families to generate larger incomes selling to local [[grocer]]s or to local outdoor markets while supplying their household with the proper nutrition of fresh and nutritional products. [[File:Ezhou-train-station-0109.jpg|thumb|rt|250px|A vegetable garden in the square in front of the train station in [[Ezhou]], China]] Some community urban farms can be quite efficient and help women find work, who in some cases are marginalized from finding employment in the formal economy.FAO. (1999). "Issues in Urban Agriculture," ''FAO Spotlight Magazine,'' January. Studies have shown that participation from women have a higher production rate, therefore producing the adequate amount for household consumption while supplying more for market sale.[http://www.idrc.ca/fr/ev-2490-201-1-DO_TOPIC.html#gender%20and%20land Mahbuba Kaneez Hasna. IDRC. CFP Report 21: NGO Gender Capacity in Urban Agriculture: Case Studies from Harare (Zimbabwe), Kampala (Uganda), and Accra (Ghana) 1998] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071218171756/http://www.idrc.ca/fr/ev-2490-201-1-DO_TOPIC.html#gender%20and%20land |date=18 December 2007 }} As most UA activities are conducted on vacant municipal land, there have been raising concerns about the allocation of land and property rights. The [[International Development Research Centre|IDRC]] and the [[Food and Agriculture Organization|FAO]] have published the Guidelines for Municipal Policymaking on Urban Agriculture, and are working with municipal governments to create successful policy measures that can be incorporated in urban planning.IDRC/ UN-HABITAT".Guidelines for Municipal Policymaking on Urban Agriculture" Urban Agriculture: Land Management and Physical Planning (2003) [http://www.ruaf.org/sites/default/files/Guideline%203%20Urban%20agriculture%20-%20Land%20Management%20and%20Physical%20Planning.pdf PDF] 1.3 Over a third of U.S. households, roughly 42 million, participate in food gardening. There has also been an increase of 63% participation in farming by millennials from 2008-2013. US households participating in community gardening has also tripled from 1 to 3 million in that time frame. Urban agriculture provides unique opportunities to bridge diverse communities together. In addition, it provides opportunities for health care providers to interact with their patients. Thus, making each community garden a hub that is reflective of the community. Alaimo, K., Beavers, A.W., Crawford, C. et al. Curr Envir Health Rpt (2016) 3: 302. https://doi.org/10.1007/s40572-016-0105-0 ===Energy efficiency=== [[File:Mushroom growing kit, BTTR Ventures.jpg|thumb|upright|Edible Oyster Mushrooms growing on used coffee grounds]] The current [[industrial agriculture]] system is accountable for high [[energy economics|energy costs]] for the [[transportation]] of foodstuffs. According to a study by Rich Pirog, the associate director of the Leopold Center for Sustainable Agriculture at Iowa State University, the average conventional produce item travels {{convert|1500|mi}},{{cite web |url=http://www.leopold.iastate.edu/pubs/staff/files/food_travel072103.pdf |title=Pirog, R. and A. Benjamin. ''"Checking the food odometer: Comparing food miles for local versus conventional produce sales to Iowa institutions"'', Leopold Center for Sustainable Agriculture, 2003 |publisher=Leopold.iastate.edu |accessdate=1 April 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120514150840/http://www.leopold.iastate.edu/pubs/staff/files/food_travel072103.pdf |archive-date=14 May 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} using, if shipped by [[tractor-trailer]], {{convert|1|USgal}} of fossil fuel per {{convert|100|lb}}.{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/03/07/AR2008030702520.html | work=The Washington Post | title=Eat Locally, Ease Climate Change Globally | date=9 March 2008 | accessdate=27 May 2010}} The energy used to transport food is decreased when urban agriculture can provide cities with locally grown food. Pirog found that traditional, non-local, food distribution system used 4 to 17 times more fuel and emitted 5 to 17 times more {{CO2}} than the local and [[Regional Transportation Plan|regional transport]].Pirog, Rich S.; Van Pelt, Timothy; Enshayan, Kamyar; and Cook, Ellen, "Food, Fuel, and Freeways: An Iowa perspective on how far food travels, fuel usage, and greenhouse gas emissions" (2001). Leopold Center Pubs and Papers. 3. http://lib.dr.iastate.edu/leopold_pubspapers/3 Similarly, in a study by Marc Xuereb and Region of Waterloo Public Health, they estimated that switching to locally grown food could save transport-related emissions equivalent to nearly 50,000 metric tons of {{CO2}}, or the equivalent of taking 16,191 cars off the road.Xuereb, Marc. (2005). "Food Miles: Environmental Implications of Food Imports to Waterloo Region." Public Health Planner Region of Waterloo Public Health. November. https://web.archive.org/web/20180128180314/http://chd.region.waterloo.on.ca/en/researchResourcesPublications/resources/FoodMiles_Report.pdf [[File:The WindowFarms Project (Drainage) @ MakerFaire.jpg|thumb|right|upright|A [[windowfarm]], incorporating discarded plastic bottles into pots for hydroponic agriculture in urban windows]] {{see also|Energy efficiency in agriculture|Efficient energy use}} ===Carbon footprint=== As mentioned above, the energy-efficient nature of urban agriculture can reduce each city's [[carbon footprint]] by reducing the amount of transport that occurs to deliver goods to the consumer.[http://www.delta-institute.org/content/urban-agriculture Delta Institute, "Urban Agriculture."] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928072314/http://www.delta-institute.org/content/urban-agriculture |date=28 September 2013 }} Web. 25 March 2013. Also, these areas can act as [[carbon sink]]s{{Cite journal|last=Rowe|first=D. Bradley|title=Green roofs as a means of pollution abatement|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0269749110004859|journal=Environmental Pollution|volume=159|issue=8–9|pages=2100–2110|doi=10.1016/j.envpol.2010.10.029|pmid=21074914|year=2011}} offsetting some of the carbon accumulation that is innate to urban areas, where pavement and buildings outnumber plants. Plants absorb atmospheric carbon dioxide ({{CO2}}) and release breathable oxygen (O2) through [[photosynthesis]]. The process of [[Carbon Sequestration]] can be further improved by combining other agriculture techniques to increase removal from the atmosphere and prevent the release of {{CO2}} during harvest time. However, this process relies heavily on the types of plants selected and the methodology of farming. Specifically, choosing plants that do not lose their leaves and [[evergreen|remain green all year]] can increase the farm's ability to sequester carbon. ===Reduction in ozone and particulate matter=== The reduction in [[ozone]] and other [[particulate matter]] can benefit human health.{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/s1352-2310(99)00144-2 |title=Air pollution in cities |journal=Atmospheric Environment |volume=33 |issue=24–25 |pages=4029–37 |year=1999 |last1=Mayer |first1=Helmut |bibcode=1999AtmEn..33.4029M }} Reducing these particulates and ozone gases could reduce [[mortality rate]]s in urban areas along with increase the health of those living in cities. Just to give one example, in the article “[[Green roof]]s as a means of pollution abatement,” the author argues that a rooftop containing 2000 m² of uncut [[grass]] has the potential to remove up to 4000 kg of particulate matter. According to the article, only one square meter of green roof is needed to offset the annual particulate matter emissions of a car.Environmental Affairs Department, City of Los Angeles. 2006. "Green Roofs - Cooling Los Angeles: A Resource Guide". http://environmentla.org/pdf/EnvironmentalBusinessProgs/Green%20Roofs%20Resource%20Guide%202007.pdf{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.envpol.2010.10.029 |pmid=21074914 |title=Green roofs as a means of pollution abatement |journal=Environmental Pollution |volume=159 |issue=8–9 |pages=2100–10 |year=2011 |last1=Rowe |first1=D. Bradley }} ===Soil decontamination=== Vacant urban lots are often victim to illegal dumping of hazardous chemicals and other wastes. They are also liable to accumulate standing water and “[[grey water]]”, which can be dangerous to public health, especially left stagnant for long periods. The implementation of urban agriculture in these vacant lots can be a cost-effective method for removing these chemicals. In the process known as [[Phytoremediation]], plants and the associated microorganisms are selected for their chemical ability to degrade, absorb, convert to an inert form, and remove toxins from the soil.Black, H. "Absorbing Possibilities: Phytoremediation." Environ Health Perspectives 103.12 (1995): 1106-108. Several chemicals can be targeted for removal including heavy metals (e.g. Mercury and lead) inorganic compounds (e.g. Arsenic and Uranium), and organic compounds (e.g. petroleum and chlorinated compounds like PBC's).Comis, Don. (2000). "Phytoremediation: Using Plants To Clean Up Soils." Agricultural Research: n. pag. Phytoremediation: Using Plants To Clean Up Soils. USDA-ARS, 13 August 2004. Web. 25 March 2013. Phytoremeditation is both an environmentally friendly, cost-effective, and energy-efficient measure to reduce pollution. Phytoremediation only costs about $5–$40 per ton of [[soil decontamination|soil being decontaminated]].{{cite journal | last1 = Lasat | first1 = M. M. | year = 2000 | title = Phytoextraction of metals from contaminated soil: a review of plant /soil/metal interaction and assessment of pertinent agronomic issues | url = | journal = Journal of Hazardous Substance Research | volume = 2 | issue = | pages = 1–25 }}[http://www.bioteach.ubc.ca/Journal/V02I01/phytoremediation.pdf Cluis, C. (2004). "Junk-greedy Greens: phytoremediation as a new option for soil decontamination,"] BioTech J. '''2''': 61-67 Implementation of this process also reduces the amount of soil that must be disposed of in a hazardous waste landfill.{{cite journal |pmid=8747015 |pmc=1519251 |year=1995 |author1=Black |first1=H |title=Absorbing possibilities: Phytoremediation |journal=Environmental Health Perspectives |volume=103 |issue=12 |pages=1106–8 |doi=10.2307/3432605|jstor=3432605 }} Urban agriculture as a method to mediate chemical pollution can be effective in preventing the spread of these chemicals into the surrounding environment. Other methods of remediation often disturb the soil and force the chemicals contained within it into the air or water. Plants can be used as a method to remove chemicals and also to hold the soil and prevent erosion of contaminated soil decreasing the spread of pollutants and the hazard presented by these lots.{{cite web|url=http://water.epa.gov/polwaste/nps/urban.cfm |title=Managing Urban Runoff | Polluted Runoff | US EPA |publisher=Water.epa.gov |accessdate=1 April 2013}} One way of identifying soil contamination is through using already well-established plants as bioindicators of soil health. Using well-studied plants is important because there has already been substantial bodies of work to test them in various conditions, so responses can be verified with certainty. Such plants are also valuable because they are genetically identical as crops as opposed to natural variants of the same species. Typically urban soil has had the topsoil stripped away and has led to soil with low aeration, porosity, and drainage. Typical measures of soil health are microbial biomass and activity, enzymes, [[soil organic matter]] (SOM), total nitrogen, available nutrients, porosity, aggregate stability, and compaction. A new measurement is active carbon (AC), which is the most usable portoin of the total organic carbon (TOC) in the soil. This contributes greatly to the functionality of the soil food web. Using common crops, which are generally well-studied, as bioindicators an be used to effectively test the quality of an urban farming plot before beginning planting. Alaimo K, Beavers AW, Crawford C, et al. (2016) Amplifying Health Through Community Gardens: A Framework for Advancing Multicomponent, Behaviorally Based Neighborhood Interventions.
